{{Infobox musical artist | name = 2562 | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = Dave Huismans | alias = A Made Up Sound
Dogdaze | birth_date =1979 | death_date = | origin = [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] | instrument = | genre = [[Future garage]], [[broken beat]], [[dubstep]], [[techno]], [[outsider house]] | occupation = [[Record producer]], [[Disc jockey|DJ]] | years_active = | label = [[Tectonic (record label)|Tectonic]] }} '''Dave Huismans''' (born 1979), better known by his [[stage name]] '''2562,''' is a musician from [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]].{{cite web|url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?926|title=2562: Dubstep in the area|date=21 July 2008|work=Resident Advisor|accessdate=17 April 2010}} Having previously released records of various musical styles under the monikers '''A Made Up Sound''' and '''Dogdaze''',{{cite web|author=zzzzamuel zzzztrang |url=http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/3432763 |title=Reviews - Album - 2562 |publisher=Drowned in Sound |date=2008-06-10 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} Huismans created 2562, under which his output is generally described as [[dubstep]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boomkat.com/item.cfm?id=95455 |title=2562, Aerial |publisher=Boomkat |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42836-2562-aerial |title=2562 - Aerial |publisher=The Skinny |date=2008-05-23 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/4332 |title=Dusted Reviews: 2562 - Aerial |publisher=Dustedmagazine.com |date=2008-06-02 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} He is known for producing dubstep that takes influence from techno as well.De opkomst van dubstep in de media ''[https://thesis.eur.nl/pub/10274/ Dr P.Berkers]'' The debut 2562 album, ''Aerial'' (Tectonic Records, 2008), was released to favourable reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |title=Sounds of the Universe — 2562 — Aerial |publisher=Soundsoftheuniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524061734/http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |archivedate=2011-05-24 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=517&Itemid=26 |title=2562's 'Aerial' view |publisher=FactMagazine |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}The Next Dubstep''[https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/aug/25/sceneandheard The Guardian]'' ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''In Dog We Trust'' (2006), Dogdaze Productions – as Dogdaze * ''Aerial'' (2008), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Shortcuts'' (produced 2004, released 2008), - as Made Up Sound * ''Unbalance'' (2009), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Fever'' (2011), When In Doubt – as 2562 * ''Air Jordan'' (2012), When In Doubt - as 2562 * ''The new today'' (2014), When In Doubt - as 2562 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://myspace.com/2562dub 2562] on [[Myspace]] * {{Discogs artist | artist = 2562 | name = 2562 }} * [http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=581&Itemid=27 ''FactMagazine'' interview (05/2008)] * [http://www.beatportal.com/feed/item/2562-video-interview/ Beatportal interview (10/2008)] * [https://archive.is/20130205211702/http://www.vectormeldrew.com/2009/08/2562-unbalance-album-artwork/ 2562 Unbalance Artwork Designer (10/2008)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2562}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Dubstep musicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from The Hague]]

{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|BLP=yes|date=February 2016}} {{third-party|date=February 2016}} }} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #F9F9F9 | name = aaajiao (aka.Xu Wenkai) | image = Aaajiao-xuwenkai.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1984|11|30}} | birth_place = [[China]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{flagicon|China}} [[People's Republic of China]] | field = [[Media Art]], [[Conceptual art]], [[Software art]], [[Networked Art]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | website = [http://eventstructure.com] }}
'''aaajiao''' （aka.Xu Wenkai） ({{zh|c= 徐文恺}}), is the online handle of Xu Wenkai, a Shanghai- and Berlin-based artist, avid blogger and free thinker.
Born in 1984, aaajiao grew up in Xi’an, the ancient capital of Qin and Han Dynasty known for the Terracotta Army. The year of 1984, coinciding with [[George Orwell]]’s dystopian masterpiece, seems to explain the perfect alignment between the vivid SciTech-driven imagination and the sometimes-poetic sophistication, frequently seen as the main theme of aaajiao’s work. Many of aaajiao’s works tap into the most current trends of thoughts around the Internet sphere, with a focus on the emerging controversies and phenomenon related to data processing, blogsphere/wemedia and filtered information. In his most recent projects, the artist has adopted a more extended scope of practices, borrowing elements from architecture, electronic music, performance arts, product design, even medicine, to portray the young generation harnessing the power of cyber technology and the ever-present social media.
Being one of the most frequently exhibited Chinese new media artists, aaajiao has been featured in both international and domestic scenes. Highlights include: “Global Control And Censorship - [[ZKM]] | Zentrum für Kunst und Medientechnologie Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe(2015)”, The 2nd “CAFAM Future” Exhibition: Observer-Creator · The Reality Representation of Chinese Young Art Beijing, CAFA Art Museum (2015); Cosmos - Limited and Limitless, Existence and Co-existence Shanghai, 21st Century Minsheng Art Museum (2014),Thingworld - International Triennial of New Media Art Beijing,The [[National Art Museum of China]] (2014),The West Bund Architecture and Contemporary Art Biennale, Shanghai (2013); “One World” Exposition – Chinese Art in the Age of the New Media, Videotage, TransLife: Media Art China 2011 - International Triennial of New Media Art Beijing,The [[National Art Museum of China]] (2011),Hong Kong (2011); [[Transmediale]], Berlin (2010), etc. aaajiao is a winner of the Jury Prize from Art Sanya Awards 2014, a nominee of OCAT – Pierre Huber Art Prize, and most recently, a nominee of the “Young Artist of the Year” of 9th “Award of Art China”.
== Selected Solo exhibitions == *2016 Remnants of an Electronic Past, [[Centre for Chinese Contemporary Art]], Manchester *2016 Remnants of an Electronic Past, OCAT Xi’an *2015 aaajiao - Untitled, Beijing, Gallery Yang *2015 Alias: aaajiao, Shanghai, [[LEO XU Projects|Leo Xu Projects]] *2014 The Screen Generation @ 9m² -Museum, Shanghai, 9m² Museum ( Goethe Open Space) *2013 The Screen Generation, Shanghai, chi K11 art space *2013The Screen Generation - Prequel Nov 2013 Beijing, C-Space *2011 Placebo, Shanghai, OtherGallery *2010 Cybernetics, Shanghai, V Arts Centre
== Selected Group Exhibitions == *2017 GLOBAL CONTROL AND CENSORSHIP, Estonia, Tallinna Kunstihoone *2017 Body Media II, Shanghai, [[Power Station of Art]] *2017 Shanghai Project Chapter 2 Exhibition: Seeds of Time, Shanghai, Himalayas Museum *2017 All Happens after Sunset... , Shanghai, MoCA Pavilion *2017 Create Spaces, Chengdu, Luxelakes·A4 Art Museum *2017 Moments and More: Documents of Culture Pavilion [wén huà guǎn] Online Art Project, Shanghai, OCAT *2017 Nominations, Three Rooms - International Touring Exhibition of Young Media Artists, Shanghai, Chronus Art Center *2016 A Strong Gale in the Dark Forest, Caochangdi, Chuangxinyi Internet Bar, Three Supermarkets, Beijing *2016 The 3rd Shenzhen Independent Animation Biennale, Shenzhen *2016 Temporal Turn: Art and Speculation in Contemporary Asia, [[Spencer Museum of Art]], Kansas, USA *2016 "Ethics of Technology" Beijing Media Art Biennale, Beijing *2016 OVERPOP, Shanghai, Yuz Museum *2016 Take Me (I’m Yours) New York, [[Jewish Museum]] *2016 The Exhibition of Annual of Contemporary Art of China, Beijing, Minsheng Art Museum *2016 The Mud of Compound Experience, G/F, No. 98 Apliu Street, Kowloon, Hong Kong *2016 HACK SPACE, Hong Kong, K11 Art Foundation Pop-up Space *2016 Heavy Artillery, Australia, Rabbit Gallery *2015 Globale: Global Control And Censorship - [[Center for Art and Media Karlsruhe|ZKM]] | Zentrum für Kunst und Medientechnologie Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe *2015 Fusion: Chinese Modern And Contemporary Art Since 1930s Wuhan, Wanlin Art Museum of Wuhan University *2015 [[Frieze Art Fair|Frieze New York]] Frame, New York *2015 The 2nd “CAFAM Future” Exhibition: Observer-Creator · The Reality Representation of Chinese Young Art, HongKong, K11 *2015 The Tell-Tale Heart, Chi Art Space, Hong Kong *2015 The 2nd “CAFAM Future” Exhibition: Observer-Creator · The Reality Representation of Chinese Young Art, Beijing, CAFA Art Museum *2014 2014 OCAT - Pierre Huber Art Prize Shortlist Exhibition The Truth About Entropy Shanghai, OCAT Contemporary Art Terminal, Shanghai *2014 Cosmos - Limited and Limitless, Existence and Co-existence Shanghai, 21st Century Minsheng Art Museum *2014 The 12th National Art Exhibition - Experimental Art, Beijing, Today Art Museum *2014 Metamorphosis of the Virtual 5+5, Shanghai, chi K11 art museum *2014 Silence - the 1990s, Paris, Balice Hertling *2014 Thingworld - International Triennial of New Media Art, Beijing, The [[National Art Museum of China]] *2014 PANDAMONIUM - Media Art From, Shanghai Berlin, Momentum *2014 Transience - Intractable Objects, Beijing, Taikang Space *2013 The West Bank Architecture and Contemporary Art Biennale, Shanghai *2013 Reading Shanghai, Leo Xu Projects *2013 Lost In The Labyrinth, New York, [[Harvestworks]] *2013 Truth, Beauty, Freedom and Money - Art After Social Media Era, Shanghai, chi K11 art space *2013 SHANGHAI SURPRISE - A GROUP SHOW ON CONTEMPORARY ART IN SHANGHAI, Shanghai, chi K11 art space

Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. ---> * http://eventstructure.com/aaajiao * http://www.artlinkart.com/en/artist/overview/70cbwxl * http://zkm.de/en/person/aaajiao-xu-wenkai * http://leoxuprojects.com/?p=3860 * http://thecreatorsproject.vice.com/show/aaajiao-xu-wenkai * https://www.artsy.net/artist/aaajiao * http://www.aaa.org.hk/Home/Search?keyword=XU%20Wenkai(%E5%BE%90%E6%96%87%E6%84%B7) * http://transmediale.de/aaajiao * https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/12/arts/international/opening-doors-in-china-for-creations-old-and-new.html?_r=1

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=December 2015}} {{notability|Biographies|date=December 2015}} }}
'''Aakanksha Bhargava''' (born 1985) is an Indian entrepreneur, and is currently{{when?|date=October 2018}} the only woman leading a large [[relocation service|relocation]] business in India.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lady CEO expands her feet in relocation business |url=http://www.aninews.in/videogallery2/43677-lady-ceo-expands-her-feet-in-relocation-business.html |work=[[Asian News International]] |accessdate=2015-12-03 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She is the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and President of PM Relocations Pvt Ltd (PMR) in [[Gurgaon]].
== Early life and education == Bhargava was born in [[Kolkata]] and later moved to [[Delhi]] in 1992. She studied at [[Tagore International School]] in Vasant Vihar, Delhi and later completed her B.Com Honours from [[Hindu College, University of Delhi|Hindu College]]. After this she went to Singapore and [[Dubai]] for further studies and completed her master's degree, [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] in Marketing from [[S P Jain School of Global Management]], Singapore and Dubai.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Mover And Shaker In The Relocation Sector {{!}} mindyourbusiness.in|url = http://www.mindyourbusiness.in/articles/1003835/a-mover-and-shaker-in-the-relocation-sector|website = www.mindyourbusiness.in|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref>
== Career == Bhargava joined PMR on 30 April 2007. Initially she was a manager in international sales, then moved on to handling corporate sales, marketing, operations and other verticals for the company. She was promoted to CEO in 2012. In 2015 she was awarded "Best Women Leader" by the Business Today Awards in the Small & Medium Enterprise segment.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Change Manager: PM Relocations- Business News|url = http://www.businesstoday.in/magazine/special/india-best-smes-winners-2015-pm-relocations-aakanksha-bhargava/story/223929.html|website = Business Today India|accessdate = 2015-12-03|date = 11 October 2015}}</ref> She was recognized for her contribution towards the entrepreneurship report submitted on behalf of PMR by [[Indian School of Business]](ISB).{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} She is also an elected member of [[PAIMA]] and IAM’s board panel.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
Bhargava opened new branches of the company in [[Bangalore]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Pune]], [[Ahmedabad]], [[Mumbai]] and [[Chennai]]. With this the company has also grown in numbers, global contracts and people.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Leading the way in the male-dominated relocation industry|url = http://mybigplunge.com/start-up/aakanksha-bhargava/|website = My Big Plunge|publisher = mybigplunge.com|accessdate = 2015-12-03|language = en-US}}</ref> During her tenure as the CEO of PMR, the company has grown from a top line of Rs 2 crore in 2010 to nearly Rs 46 crore in 2015.<ref name=":0" />
She has written articles for the education portal ''Education Insider'',<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bringing professionalism to an unorganised sector|url = http://www.educationinsider.net/detail_news.php?id=2358|website = www.educationinsider.net|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref> MindYourBusiness<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dancing Is A Liberating Experience: Aakanksha Bhargava {{!}} mindyourbusiness.in|url = http://www.mindyourbusiness.in/articles/1003359/dancing-is-a-liberating-experience-aakanksha-bhargava#sthash.ypjiGbsG.dpuf|website = www.mindyourbusiness.in|accessdate = 2015-12-03}}</ref> and for the [[Indo-German Chamber of Commerce]].
== Awards and recognition== * Awarded as Women Of Worth- - By [https://www.outlookbusiness.com/specials/women-of-worth_2017 Outlook Business Magazine] * Best Woman Leader - [[Business Today (business magazine)|Business Today]] SME Awards 2015.<ref name=":0" /> * Woman Entrepreneur of The Year - Franchise India Awards 2016.<ref name=":0" /> * Won 'People Management Approach by an FMB' by SPJIMR Family Managed Business Awards 2017 <ref name=":0" /> * Nominated for the 'Entrepreneur of the Year in Service Business - SCM & Logistics' at the 7th Annual Entrepreneur India Awards <ref name=":0" /> * Nominated for the 10th IWEC Awards 2017 <ref name=":0" />
== References == <references /> [[Category:Indian chief executives]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian women chief executives]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Kolkata]] [[Category:Businesswomen from West Bengal]]

{{advert|date=October 2011}}
{{Infobox artist |name = Ahmad Aali |image = Portraitofaali.jpg |caption = Ahmad Aali, 2009 |birth_name = Ahmad Aali |birth_date = 1935 |birth_place = [[Tabriz, Iran]] |nationality = [[Iran|Iranian (Iran)]] |field = [[Photographer]] }}
'''Ahmad Aali''' ({{lang-fa|احمد عالی}}, (born 1935 in [[Tabriz]]) is an [[Iran]]ian photographer and artist.
==Solo exhibitions== * 1963 Talar e Farhang * 1965 Talar e Iran (Ghandriz) * 1968 Borghes Gallery * 1968 Seyhoun Gallery * 1970 French Association * 1997 Barg Gallery (on the look for 42 years) * 2008 Aria Gallery * 2010 Mah-e Mehr Gallery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=227565|title=Tehran gallery holds photographer Ahmad Aali retrospective |newspaper=[[Tehran Times]]}}</ref> * 2012 Aaran Gallery (Recycle),Tehran<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aarangallery.com/exhibitions/recycled/|title=Aaran Gallery ( Recycle )|website=Aaran Gallery}}</ref> * 2016 Emkan Art Gallery (Ahmad Aali's Self-Portrait with G 11),Tehran<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://1emkan.com/en/exhibitions/self-portraits.html|title=Ahmad Aali’s Self-portraits with G11|last=Nadjmabadi|first=Mehrdad}}</ref> * 2018 Azad Art Gallery (Recycled 2), Tehran, Iran
==Selected Group Exhibitions== * “ ART 77 “ Washington, USA 1977 - photograph * La photographie Iranienne, Paris, France oct.2011 “Un regard sur la cre’ation contemporaine en Iran “ (photograph) * “ Iran Modern “ Asia Society Museum, Yale University, New York, sep.6.2013 - jan.5.2014 (photograph - painting) * Fotografia Europea 018, “REVOLUTIONS. Upheavals, Changes, Utopias, Fondazione Palazzo Magnani and Comune di Reggio Emilia, Italy 2018
==Publications== * Ahmad Aali, "Selection of Paintings and Photographs 1953 - 2014", Nazar Publication 2016<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nazarpub.com|title=Nazar Publication|last=|first=|date=|website=www.nazarpub.com|publisher=}}</ref> * Ahmad Aali, "Selection of works, 1961–2009", Nazar Publication 2010<ref name=":0" /> * A brief review on the creative photography of Iran 40’s and 50’s Faeghe Shokouh Nikoui (Anita) 2003, Azad University of art and architecture * History of development of alternative Techniques of photography, Photomontage and photocollage Mehrnegar Fariborz 2001, Azad University of art and architecture * Life and works of Ahmad Aali by Farhad Ranjbaran, 1998, Azad University of art and architecture
==Bibliography== Interviews, critics, published articles and essays about photography
'''Before 1979 (before Iranian Revolution)''' More than 18 published materials in: Khoushe, Keyhan international, Journal de Teheran, Tehran Journal, Bamshad Magazine, Etela’at newspaper, Tamasha Magazine, Tasvir Magazine, Ayandegan Magazine, Donya-ye Jadid Magazine, Omid-e Iran Magazine.
'''After 1979 (after Iranian Revolution)''' More than 18 published materials in: Aks Magazine, Kelk Magazine, Hamshahri newspaper, Mehr Magazine, Salam newspaper, Eghtesad newspaper, Akhabr newspoaper, Rooz-e Haftom weekley magazine, Zaman Monthley magazine, visual art’s magazine, Me’yar magazine, Iran newspaper, Tandis Magazine, Etemad Magazine, Herfeh Honarmand magazine.
==See also== * [[Culture of Iran]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[Iranian art]] * [[List of Iranian artists]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321195341/http://www.mahe-mehr.com/news_fa.php?action=view&id=836 Ahmad Aali, book launch at Mah-e Mehr Art Center (in persian)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120321195350/http://www.mahe-mehr.com/news_fa.php?action=view&id=835 Ahmad Aali, book launch at Mah-e Mehr Art Center (in persian)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120308185657/http://www.tavoosonline.com/Gallery/GalleryDetailEn.aspx?src=159 Photo exhibition by Ahmad Aali - Tavoos Art Ezine] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121013185602/http://www.mehrnews.com/en/NewsDetail.aspx?NewsID=1160014 Tehran gallery holds photographer Ahmad Aali retrospective]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Alec Mikael Aalto''' (born. 24 September 1942 [[Helsinki]]) is a Finnish diplomat.<ref>{{cite book |author=Tuominen, Tia |title=Suomen lakimiehet 2015 Finlands jurister |url= |location=Helsinki |publisher=Talentum |pages=1–2 |date= |isbn=978-952-14-2536-3}} {{fi}}</ref> In the [[Ministry for Foreign Affairs (Finland)|Foreign Ministry]], he started in 1979 and served as Finland's Ambassador in [[Austria]] (1991-1995), [[Italy]] (2003-2006) and [[Sweden]] in 2006-2010 until his retirement.
==Education== Aalto graduated as a bachelor of law in 1967 from the [[University of Helsinki]]. Between 1968 and 1970 he studied [[international law]] at [[Oxford University]].<ref name=cv>{{cite web |url= http://www.finland.se/public/default.aspx?contentid=104950 |title=Suurlähettiläs Alec Aallon curriculum vitae|last=|first= |date=|website=|publisher=Suomen suurlähetystö, Tukholma|access-date=|quote= }}</ref><ref name=tuk>{{cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703174604/http://web.tukholma.net/lue/sth_projekti/haastattelut/alec_aalto.asp |title= Suurlähettiläs Alec Aalto |last=Korhonen|first= Matti J. |date=|website=|publisher= Internet Archive|access-date=|quote= }}</ref>
==Career== Between 1970 and 1972 Aalto worked as a journalist for [[Finnish Broadcasting Company]], after which he was from 1973 to 1975 Head of Information department in the [[Council of State (Finland)|Council of State]].<ref name=cv/> He also served as the Head of Press Affairs in the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|European Security and Cooperation Conference]].<ref name=tuk/> In Aalto was in 1975 in the Prime Minister Keijo Liinama's caretaker cabinet as Prime Minister's secretary<ref name=tuk/> and from 1976 to 1978, the information director of [[Neste|Neste Oy]].<ref name=cv/>
Aalto joined the Ministry for Foreign Affairs in 1979. Until 1984 he served as the Head of the Ministry's Press and Culture Center, in 1985 as the Negotiating Officer of the Trade Policy Department and in 1986-1991 as Deputy Director of the Department of Trade Policy.<ref name=cv/>
===Work as ambassador=== In 1991, Aalto started as an Ambassador in [[Austria]] while acting as a Permanent Representative of Finland in the [[Vienna International Centre|UN organizations]] in [[Vienna]] and was accredited also in [[Slovenia]]. Between 1995 and 1997, Aalto worked as Prime Minister's Special Assistant in the Council of the State in international affairs. In 1997-2003 he was State Secretary for European Affairs and in 2000-2003 also Head of the EU Secretariat of the Council of State.<ref name=cv/>
Between 2003-2006 Aalto was Finland's Ambassador in [[Italy]], accredited to [[Malta]] and [[San Marino]]. In June 2006, he started his last ward as Ambassador in [[Sweden]].<ref name=cv/> Aalto retired in February in 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.finland.se/public/default.aspx?contentid=184676&contentlan=1&culture=fi-FI |title= Suurlähettiläs Alec Aalto jättää Tukholman |last=|first= |date=|website=|publisher=Suomen suurlähetystö, Tukholma |access-date=|quote= }}</ref>
==Personal life== Aalto's parents are actress Märta Laurent and Commercial Counselor Arvo Mikael Aalto. He is bilingual. He has a wife and daughter.<ref name=cv/> Aalto plays music and enjoys the countryside, in the archipelago and in Lapland.<ref name=tuk/>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aalto, Alec}} [[Category:Permanent Representatives of Finland to the United Nations]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to Italy]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to Austria]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to Slovenia]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to Malta]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to San Marino]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Finland to Sweden]] [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Finnish journalists]] [[Category:Finnish jurists]] [[Category:People from Helsinki]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=June 2013}} {{Globalize|date=December 2012}} }} An '''alternative lifestyle''' is a [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] diverse in respect to [[mainstream]] ones, or generally perceived to be outside the cultural [[Norm (sociology)|norm]]. ''Lifestyle'' is a [[media culture]] term derived from the concept of [[style in art]].Bernstein, J. M. ''Introduction'', in [[Adorno]] ''[[Culture industry]]'' p.35 quotation: {{quotation|Diversity is more effectively present in mass media than previously, but this is not an obvious or unequivocal gain. By the late 1950s the homogenization of consciousness had become counterproductive for the purposes of capital expansion; new needs for new commodities had to be created, and this required the reintroduction of the minimal negativity that had been previously eliminated. The cult of the new that had been the prerogative of art throughout the modernist epoch into the period of post-war unification and stabilization has returned to capital expansion from which it originally sprang. But this negativity is neither shocking nor emancipatory since it does not presage a transformation of the fundamental structures of everyday life. On the contrary, through the culture industry capital has co-opted the dynamics of negation both diachronically in its restless production of new and ‘different’ commodities and synchronically in its promotion of alternative ‘life-styles’.
‘Life-styles’, the culture industry’s recycling of style in art, represent the transformation of an aesthetic category, which once possessed a moment of negativity [shocking, emancipatory], into a quality of commodity consumption.}} Usually, but not always, it implies an affinity or identification within some matching [[subculture]] (e.g. [[hippies]], [[Goth subculture|goths]] and [[Punk subculture|punks]]). Some people with alternative lifestyles mix elements from various subcultures ([[grunge]] musicians were often influenced by a mixture of the [[punk subculture|punk]], [[acid rock|hippie]], [[emo]] and [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] subcultures). Not all minority lifestyles are held{{by whom|date=June 2014}} to be "alternative", so the term tends to apply to newer forms of lifestyle, often based upon enlarged freedoms (especially in the sphere of social styles), or a decision to substitute another approach, or to not follow the usual expected path in most societies. == History == Alternative lifestyles and subcultures originated in the 1920s{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=f5rLCgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=the+flapper+women&ots=kv9L6jn-h-&sig=8djPjwlb-1GHEYp_SKWp-gpfLsE#v=snippet&q=flapper&f=false|title=Modern women on trial: Sexual transgression in the age of the flapper|last=Bland|first=Lucy|date=2013-09-30|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9781847798961|language=en}}{{better source|date=September 2018}} with the "[[flapper]]" movement, when women cut their hair and skirts short (as a symbol of freedom from oppression and the old way of living). Women in the flapper age were the first large group of females to practice pre-marital sex, dancing, cursing, and driving in modern America without scandal following them.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} A [[Stanford University]] cooperative house, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160730005004/http://web.stanford.edu/group/synergy/ Synergy], was founded in 1972 with the theme of "exploring alternative lifestyles." ==Examples == [[File:1981 Camping. Mobile Homes 54 copy.jpg|thumb|[[Housetrucker]]s. Photo taken at the 1981 [[Nambassa]] 5 day festival]] The following are examples which may{{weasel inline|date=September 2018}}{{better source|date=September 2018}} be considered by some{{who|date=September 2018}}{{why|date=September 2018}}{{when|date=September 2018}} to be alternative lifestyles: * Alternative [[child-rearing]], such as [[homeschooling]], [[coparenting]] and [[home births]] * Restrictive dieting, such as [[veganism]], [[vegetarianism]], [[freeganism]], or [[raw foodism]] * Living in unusual communities, such as [[commune]]s, [[Intentional community|intentional communities]], [[ecovillage]]s, [[off-the-grid]], or the [[tiny house movement]] * Traveling [[subcultures]], including [[lifestyle traveller]]s, [[housetrucker|housetrucking]], and [[New Age travellers|New Age travelling]] * [[Body modification]], including [[tattoos]], [[body piercings]], [[Suspension (body modification)|suspension]], and [[transdermal implants]] * [[Nudism]] and [[clothing optional]] lifestyles * Non-normative sexual lifestyles, such as [[BDSM]], [[polyamory]], [[Swinging (sexual practice)|swinging]], and certain types of [[sexual fetishism]] or [[paraphilia]]{{cite book|last1=Makai|first1=Michael|title=Domination & Submission: The BDSM Relationship Handbook|date=September 2013|publisher=Createspace|isbn=1492775975}} * [[Alternative medicine]] and natural methods of medical care or [[herbal remedies]] as medication * Adherents to alternative [[spirituality|spiritual]] and religious practices, such as [[vampire lifestyle|vampirism]], [[Wicca]], [[Neopaganism]], [[Satanism]], or [[cults]] * Certain religious minorities, such as the [[Amish]] who pursue a non-technological or [[anti-technology]] lifestyle ==See also== * [[Alternative culture]] * [[Bohemianism]] * [[Intentional community]] * [[Intentional living]] * [[Subculture]] * [[Underground culture]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://cgi.stanford.edu/~group-synergy/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Main.HomePage/ Synergy House at Stanford University] {{DEFAULTSORT:Alternative Lifestyle}} [[Category:Subcultures]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]] [[Category:Deviance (sociology)]]

{{Use British English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Wolverhampton]], [[England]] | image = | caption = | death_date = | birth_name = | occupation = Actor | nationality = British | years active = 2009–present | website = {{url|http://www.AntonioAakeel.com/}} }}
'''Antonio Aakeel''' is an English actor. He was named by [[Screen International]] as a 2018 Star of Tomorrow for his leading role in ''[[Eaten by Lions (film)|Eaten by Lions]]'' and appeared opposite [[Alicia Vikander]] in Warner Bros.' ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' reboot.<ref>{{cite web |title=Stars of Tomorrow |url=https://www.screendaily.com/features/stars-of-tomorrow-2018-antonio-aakeel-actor/5133183.article |website=Screen Daily |accessdate=8 November 2018 |ref=Screen International}}</ref> He is known for appearing in the [[BAFTA]] award-winning series ''[[Three Girls (miniseries)|Three Girls]]'', ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' and was cast alongside [[Riz Ahmed]] in the 2016 thriller ''[[City of Tiny Lights]]''.
== Early life == Aakeel was born in [[Wolverhampton]], [[England]], and moved around the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] as a child.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wolverhampton actor secures feature-length international film role|url=http://nativemonster.com/film-and-theatre/film/wolverhampton-actor-secures-feature-length-international-film-role|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=NativeMonster}}</ref> He caught the acting bug after being given a one-line role in a school nativity play and went on to hone his craft through local theatre, before being scouted by a talent agent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Birmingham actor makes Hollywood Debut|url=http://whatsonlive.co.uk/birmingham/news/birmingham-actor-makes-hollywood-debut/36060|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=What's On Birmingham}}</ref> He speaks [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] and [[Hindi]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview with Antonio Aakeel|url=http://scottishasianmagazine.com/interview-antonio-aakeel/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Scottish Asian Magazine}}</ref>
== Career ==
===Film===
Aakeel starred as Nasir Baloch in the 2013 political short film ''[[The Line of Freedom (film)|The Line of Freedom]]'' directed by David Whitney. The film depicts the true story of a murdered student rights activist and premiered at the [[Dubai International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Line of Freedom Premiere|url=https://dubaifilmfest.com/en/films/23961/the_line_of_freedom.html|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Dubai Film Festival}}</ref> Upon its release, the film was immediately met with controversy and allegedly resulted in Aakeel becoming a target of death threats.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where Is The Mainstream Coverage Of The Crisis In Balochistan?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/where-is-the-mainstream-coverage-of-the-crisis-in-balochistan_us_57da9edee4b0d5920b5b25b2|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=16 Sep 2016}}</ref> The film was subsequently prohibited in Pakistan and reportedly contributed to a national ban of [[IMDb]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Line of Freedom and the brief IMDb ban in Pakistan|url=https://globalvoices.org/2013/12/01/the-line-of-freedom-and-the-brief-imdb-ban-in-pakistan/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Global Voices}}</ref>
In 2015, he appeared as Raza in feature film ''[[The Contract (2015 Film)|The Contract]]'', written by [[David Marconi]] and directed by Nic Auerbach.
He was cast alongside [[Riz Ahmed]] and [[Billie Piper]] in London crime thriller ''[[City of Tiny Lights (film)|City of Tiny Lights]]'' directed by [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] winner [[Pete Travis]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the young cast of City of Tiny Lights|url=http://screenterrier.blogspot.co.uk/2016/09/meet-young-cast-of-city-of-tiny-lights.html|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=ScreenTerrier}}</ref> The film had its world premiere at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] 2016 and released in UK cinemas April 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Popular Birmingham actor to make big screen debut|url=https://iambirmingham.co.uk/2016/07/15/birmingham-actor-to-make-big-screen-debut/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=I Am Birmingham}}</ref>
In December 2016, Aakeel landed a supporting role in ''The Hungry'', [[Film London| Film London's]] contemporary feature adaptation of [[Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] [[Titus Andronicus]] alongside [[Naseeruddin Shah]] and [[Tisca Chopra]], directed by Bornila Chatterjee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the Birmingham actor who has been cast in an international Shakespeare film|url=http://stylebham.com/life/meet-birmingham-actor-cast-international-shakespeare-film|accessdate=20 Jan 2017|publisher=StyleBham}}</ref> The Film premiered under special presentations at the 2017 [[Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Hungry - TIFF|url=http://www.tiff.net/tiff/the-hungry/|website=tiff.net|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref>
It was announced in March 2017 that Aakeel will star as the lead in British feature film ''[[Eaten by Lions (film)|Eaten by Lions]]'', starring opposite comedians [[Johnny Vegas]] and [[Jack Carroll (comedian)|Jack Carroll]], directed by Jason Wingard.<ref>{{cite news|title=Antonio Aakeel to star as lead in British feature Eaten by Lions|url=http://www.identityschoolofacting.com/antonio-aak%CE%BE%CE%BEl-announced-as-lead-role-in-new-feature-eaten-by-lions/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=IAG}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BHAM MAIL|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/billie-piper-helps-peaky-blinders-12848465|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref>
Aakeel appeared opposite [[Academy Awards|Oscar]]-winning actress [[Alicia Vikander]] in the franchise reboot ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' (2018), directed by [[Roar Uthaug]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Birmingham actor Antonio Aakeel to star with Alicia Vikander in Tomb Raider re-boot|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/film-news/tomb-raider-antonio-aakeel-alicia-12848465|website=Birmingham Mail|accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
===Television===
Aakeel landed his first television role in the British series ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]''. He was chosen over 500 hopefuls by director [[Charles Martin (director)|Charles Martin]] and appeared in series 3 of the [[E4 (TV channel)|E4]] drama.<ref>{{cite web|title=Antonio Aakeel - NewUrban|url=http://www.new-urban.co/antonio-aakeel/|publisher=NUBI|accessdate=31 October 2016}}</ref>
He has gained guest-lead roles in [[BBC]] series ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'' and [[BBC One]] drama series ''[[Moving On (TV series)|Moving On]]'' directed by [[Reece Dinsdale]].<ref>{{cite news|title=BBC Doctors|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04bmv4j/credits|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Antonio Aakeel will star in BBC series Moving On|url=http://us4.campaign-archive1.com/?u=ae8e3d09be1e9c6b15ce45e66&id=68475a4b7a|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Identity Drama}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Moving On returns as BBC One reveals new commissions|url=http://www.prolificnorth.co.uk/2016/10/moving-on-returns-as-bbc-one-reveals-new-commissions/|website=Prolific North|accessdate=31 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BBC's Doctors to explore gender identity issues for the first time|url=http://www.gaytimes.co.uk/culture/52307/bbcs-doctors-explore-gender-identity-issues-first-time/|accessdate=31 October 2016|publisher=GayTimes.co.uk}}</ref>
In 2016, Aakeel was cast in ''Guilty Pleasures'' directed by Sonny Michael Chohan, a TV drama pilot based on real life [[sex trafficking]] circles in the [[UK]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Child grooming drama to premiere in Birmingham|url=https://iambirmingham.co.uk/2016/08/08/child-grooming-drama-premieres-in-birmingham/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=I Am Birmingham}}</ref>
In May 2017 he appeared in the three-part [[BBC One]] drama ''Three Girls'' directed by [[BAFTA]] winner [[Philippa Lowthorpe]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Antonio Aakeel set to appear in BBC drama|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/14841782.Antonio_Aakeel_set_to_appear_in_BBC_drama__Moving_On_/|website=Asian Image|accessdate=3 Nov 2016}}</ref>
===Theatre===
In 2013, he played the title role in the stage adaptation of ''Guantanamo Boy''. The play ran at the [[Half Moon Theatre]] and toured nationally at [[Middle Temple|Middle Temple Hall]], [[Almeida Theatre]], [[The Hat Factory]], [[Mercury Theatre, Colchester|Mercury Theatre]], [[Burnley Youth Theatre]] and [[The Drum (Arts Centre)|The Drum Theatre]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Review: Guantanamo Boy|url=https://www.halfmoon.org.uk/review-guantanamo-boy-childrens-theatre-reviews/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=Children's Theatre Reviews}}</ref> [[The Stage]]'s Susan Elkin wrote Aakeel "is great as the distraught, anguished, terrified Khalid. The downhill spiral followed by the final return of a damaged-for-life boy to Rochdale is well handled too. He has a very expressive face."<ref>{{cite news|title=Guantanamo Boy Theatre Review - WhatsonStage Susan Elkin|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/reviews/11-2013/guantanamo-boy_32626.html|accessdate=23 August 2016|publisher=WhatsonStage.com}}</ref>
In 2015, he played the lead role of Artie in ''Waiting for Garbo'' at the [[Crescent Theatre]] as part of the Birmingham Theatre Festival. Love Midlands Theatre reviewed the performance, commenting his "portrayal of a brash New Yorker falling apart is utterly convincing."<ref>{{cite news|title=Waiting For Garbo Theatre Review|url=http://www.lovemidlandstheatre.co.uk/reviews/a-play-that-leaves-you-thinking|accessdate=23 August 2016|publisher=Love Midlands Theatre}}</ref>
Antonio has also performed locally with [[The Midlands|Midlands]] based theatre company Round Midnight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Follow me theatre play a success|url=http://redditchstandard.co.uk/news/round-midnights-follow-success-redditch/|accessdate=15 September 2016|publisher=The Redditch Standard}}</ref>
== Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Film |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 2013 || ''[[The Line of Freedom (film)|The Line of Freedom]]'' || Nasir Baloch || |- | 2015 || ''[[The Contract (2015 Film)|The Contract]]'' || Raza || |- | 2016 || ''[[City of Tiny Lights (film)|City of Tiny Lights]]'' || 'Young' Lovely || |- | 2017 || ''[[The Hungry]]'' || Chirag Joshi || |- | 2017 || ''[[Eaten by Lions (film)|Eaten by Lions]]'' || Omar || |- | 2018 || ''[[Tomb Raider (film)|Tomb Raider]]'' || Nitin Ahuja || |}
{| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Television |- ! Year !! Title !! Role |- | 2009 || ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' || Trevor |- | 2014 || ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'' || Aasim Masood |- | rowspan="3" | 2016 | ''Guilty Pleasures'' || Imi |- | ''[[Doctors (2000 TV series)|Doctors]]'' || Mark 'Stotty' Stott |- | ''[[Moving On (TV series)|Moving On]]'' || Mati Ahmadi |- | 2017 || ''[[Three Girls (miniseries)|Three Girls]]'' || Immy |}

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 797492686 by [[Special:Contributions/KolbertBot|KolbertBot]] ([[User talk:KolbertBot|talk]]): If Artificial Intel Chem is something entirely different, we shouldn't be describing it here. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
An '''artificial chemistry''' <ref name="BY2015">W. Banzhaf and L. Yamamoto. [https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/artificial-chemistries Artificial Chemistries], MIT Press, 2015. </ref> <ref name="Dittrich2012">P. Dittrich. [https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4614-1800-9_13 Artificial chemistry (AC)] In A. R. Meyers (ed.), Computational Complexity: Theory, Techniques, and Applications, pp. 185-203, Springer, 2012.</ref> <ref name="DZB2001">P. Dittrich, J. Ziegler, and W. Banzhaf. [http://web.cs.mun.ca/~banzhaf/papers/alchemistry_review_MIT.pdf Artificial chemistries — A review]. Artificial Life, 7(3):225–275, 2001. </ref> is a chemical-like system that usually consists of objects, called molecules, that interact according to rules resembling chemical reaction rules. Artificial chemistries are created and studied in order to understand fundamental properties of chemical systems, including prebiotic evolution, as well as for developing chemical computing systems. Artificial chemistry is a field within computer science wherein chemical reactions—often biochemical ones—are computer-simulated, yielding insights on evolution, self-assembly, and other biochemical phenomena. The field does not use actual chemicals, and should not be confused with either synthetic chemistry or computational chemistry. Rather, bits of information are used to represent the starting molecules, and the end products are examined along with the processes that led to them. The field originated in [[artificial life]] but has shown to be a versatile method with applications in many fields such as [[chemistry]], [[economics]], [[sociology]] and [[linguistics]].
==Formal definition== An artificial chemistry is defined in general as a triple (S,R,A). In some cases it is sufficient to define it as a tuple (S,I).
*S is the [[Set (mathematics)|set]] of possible molecules S={s<sub>1</sub>...,s<sub>n</sub>}, where n is the number of elements in the set, possibly infinite. *R is a set of [[arity|n-ary]] [[operation (mathematics)|operation]]s on the molecules in S, the reaction rules R={r<sub>1</sub>...,r<sub>n</sub>}. Each rule r<sub>i</sub> is written like a chemical reaction a+b+c->a*+b*+c*. Note here that r<sub>i</sub> are operators, as opposed to +. *A is an [[algorithm]] describing how to apply the rules R to a [[subset]] P<math>\subset</math>S. *I are the interaction rules of the molecules in S.
==Types of artificial chemistries==
* depending on the space of possible molecules ** finite ** infinite * depending on the type of reactions ** catalytic systems ** reactive systems ** inhibitive systems * depending on the space topology ** well stirred reactor ** topologically arranged (1-, 2-, and 3-dimensional)
==Important concepts== * The field is heavily reliant on mathematics, to include mathematical modeling. It in fact relies more on a mathematics background than a chemistry background. * Organizations: An organization is a set of molecules that is closed and self-maintaining. As such, it is a set that does not create anything outside itself, and such that any molecule inside the set can be generated within the set. * Closed sets * Self-maintaining sets * Hasse diagram of organizations
==History of artificial chemistries==
Artificial chemistries emerged as a sub-field of [[artificial life]], in particular from [[strong artificial life]]. The idea behind this field was that if one wanted to build something alive, it had to be done by a combination of non-living entities. For instance, a cell is itself alive, and yet is a combination of non-living molecules. Artificial chemistry enlists, among others, researchers that believe in an extreme bottom-up approach to artificial life. In artificial life, bits of information were used to represent bacteria or members of a species, each of which moved, multiplied, or died in computer simulations. In artificial chemistry bits of information are used to represent starting molecules capable of reacting with one another. The field has pertained to artificial intelligence by virtue of the fact that, over billions of years, non-living matter evolved into primordial life forms which in turn evolved into intelligent life forms.
==Important contributors==
The first reference about Artificial Chemistries come from a Technical paper written by [[John McCaskill]] .<ref>J.S.McCaskill. Polymer chemistry on tape: A computational model for emergent genetics. Technical report, MPI for Biophysical Chemistry, 1988.</ref> [[Walter Fontana]] working with [[Leo Buss]] then took up the work developing the [[AlChemy model]] <ref>W. Fontana. Algorithmic chemistry. In C. G. Langton, C. Taylor, J. D. Farmer, and S. Rasmussen, editors, Artificial Life II, pages 159–210. Westview Press, 1991.</ref> .<ref name="FB1994">W. Fontana and L. Buss. “The arrival of the fittest”: Toward a theory of biological organization. Bulletin of Mathematical Biology, 56(1):1–64, 1994.</ref> The model was presented at the second International Conference of Artificial Life. In his first papers he presented the concept of [[organization]], as a set of molecules that is algebraically closed and self-maintaining. This concept was further developed by Dittrich and Speroni di Fenizio into a theory of chemical organizations <ref>P. Dittrich, P. Speroni di Fenizio. [https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11538-006-9130-8 Chemical Organization Theory]. Bulletin of Mathematical Biology (2007) 69: 1199:1231.</ref> .<ref>P. Speroni di Fenizio. Chemical Organization Theory. PhD thesis, Friedrich Schiller University Jena, 2007.</ref>
Two main schools of artificial chemistries have been in Japan and Germany. In Japan the main researchers have been [[Takashi Ikegami]] ,<ref>T. Ikegami and T. Hashimoto. Active mutation in self-reproducing networks of machines and tapes. Artificial Life, 2(3):305–318, 1995.</ref> <ref>T. Ikegami and T.Hashimoto. Replication and diversity in machine-tape coevolutionary systems. In C. G. Langton and K. Shimohara, editors, Artificial Life V, pages 426–433. MIT Press, 1997.</ref> [[Hideaki Suzuki]] <ref>H.Suzuki. Models for the conservation of genetic information with string-based artificial chemistry. In W. Banzhaf, J. Ziegler, T. Christaller, P. Dittrich, and J. T. Kim, editors, Advances in Artificial Life, volume 2801 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, pages 78–88. Springer, 2003.</ref> <ref>H. Suzuki. A network cell with molecular agents that divides from centrosome signals. Biosystems, 94(1-2):118–125, 2008.</ref> and [[Yasuhiro Suzuki]] <ref>Y. Suzuki, J. Takabayashi, and H. Tanaka. Investigation of tritrophic interactions in an ecosystem using abstract chemistry. Artificial Life and Robotics, 6(3):129–132, 2002.</ref> .<ref>Y. Suzuki and H. Tanaka. Modeling p53 signaling pathways by using multiset processing. In G. Ciobanu, G. Pa ̆un, and M. J. Pérez-Jiménez, editors, Applications of Membrane Computing, Natural Computing Series, pages 203–214. Springer, 2006.</ref> In [[Germany]], it was [[Wolfgang Banzhaf]], who, together with his students [[Peter Dittrich]] and [[Jens Ziegler]], developed various artificial chemistry models. Their 2001 paper 'Artificial Chemistries - A Review' <ref name="DZB2001" /> became a standard in the field. [[Jens Ziegler]], as part of his PhD thesis, proved that an artificial chemistry could be used to control a small Khepera robot .<ref>J.Ziegler and W.Banzhaf. Evolving control metabolisms for a robot. ArtificialLife, 7(2):171–190, 2001.</ref> Among other models, [[Peter Dittrich]] developed the [[Seceder model]] which is able to explain group formation in society through some simple rules. Since then he became a professor in [[Jena]] where he investigates artificial chemistries as a way to define a general theory of [[constructive dynamical system]]s.
==Applications of artificial chemistries==
Artificial Chemistries are often used in the study of protobiology, in trying to bridge the gap between [[chemistry]] and [[biology]]. A further motivation to study artificial chemistries is the interest in constructive dynamical systems. Yasuhiro Suzuki has modeled various systems such as membrane systems, signaling pathways (P53), ecosystems, and enzyme systems by using his method, abstract rewriting system on multisets (ARMS).
==See also== *[[Avida]] Digital Evolution *[[Cellular automaton|Cellular automata]] *[[Computational chemistry]] - the use of simplified models to simulate chemical interactions
==External links == *[http://www.artificial-chemistries.org/ Artificial Chemistries website] <ref name="BY2015" /> *[http://www.sq3.org.uk/wiki.pl?Papers Tim Hutton's Papers & Talks] - includes several papers on artificial chemistries for artificial life <!---- *[http://www.minet.uni-jena.de/~biosys/twiki/bin/view.pl/ACHEM/WebHome the ARTIFICIAL CHEMISTRY webpage] of [[Peter Dittrich]]'s workgroup. ---> *[http://protobiology.org the protobiology.org website]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Artificial life]]

revision.comment: /* References */add authority control, test
revision.text:
'''Beth Aala''' is a three-time award winning<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.documentary.org/project/made-boise|title=Made in Boise|publisher=}}</ref> American documentary filmmaker and film producer.<ref name="manillaTimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.pressreader.com/philippines/manila-times/20111228/281921654896609|via=PressReader.com|publisher=Manilla Times|title=Fil-Am Beth Aala wins third Emmy}}</ref>
==Life== Aala's parents emigrated from the Philippines to the United States,<ref name="manillaTimes"/> where she was born. She attended Elk Grove High School in Sacramento.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egcitizen.com/lifestyle/super-grads-making-history/article_1b6c8212-5e3a-56df-a3a5-1ca674f62fb2.html|title=Super Grads – Making History|publisher=}}</ref> Aala received a bachelor's degree from [[UC San Diego]] in both Visual Arts and Communication.<ref>http://www.philstar.com:8080/entertainment/738704/more-just-wiltime-1st-year-celebration</ref>
==Film career== Aala is best known for her 2013 film, ''[[Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon]],'' which she co-directed and produced with comedian [[Mike Myers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/film-review-supermensch-the-legend-of-shep-gordon-1201217356/|title=Film Review: ‘Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon’|first=Justin|last=Chang|date=10 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2016/09/28/films/shep-gordon-lives-life-like-movie/|title=Shep Gordon lives life like a movie - The Japan Times|publisher=}}</ref>
She was the codirector, with Susan Froemke and John Hoffman, of the film ''[[Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman]],'' which premiered at the [[Sundance film festival]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/rancher-farmer-fisherman-film-review-sundance-2017-966841|title='Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman': Film Review - Sundance 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/reviews/rancher-farmer-fisherman-sundance-film-review-1201966543/|title=Sundance Film Review: ‘Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman’|first=Dennis|last=Harvey|date=24 January 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==Awards== In 2005, Aala won an [[Emmy Award]] for co-producing ''[[I Have Tourette's but Tourette's Doesn't Have Me]].''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/11/arts/television/children-persevering-in-the-face-of-tourettes.html|title=Children Persevering in the Face of Tourette's|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> She also received Emmys for producing in the "Outstanding Children's Program" category in 2008 and 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/bios/beth-aala|title=Beth Aala - Television Academy|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2006, she won a [[Peabody Award]] for co-producing the film ''[[The Music in Me]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/the-music-in-me|title=The Music in Me|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aala, Beth}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women film producers]] [[Category:American film producers]] [[Category:American women film directors]] [[Category:American people of Filipino descent]]

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A series of changes of form that an organism undergoes, returning to the starting state" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A series of changes of form that an organism undergoes, returning to the starting state}} [[File:Culex mosquito life cycle en.svg|thumb|Life cycle of a [[mosquito]]. An adult (imago) lays eggs which develop through several stages to adulthood. Reproduction completes and perpetuates the cycle.]] [[File:Babesia life cycle human en.svg|thumb|240px|Life cycle of the single-celled parasite ''[[Babesia]]''.]] In [[biology]], a '''biological life cycle''' (or just '''life cycle''' when the biological context is clear) is a series of changes in form that an organism undergoes, returning to the starting state. "The concept is closely related to those of the life history, [[Developmental biology|development]] and [[ontogeny]], but differs from them in stressing renewal."<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/55494?uid=3739448&uid=2&uid=3737720&uid=4&sid=21103764585297 |author1=Graham Bell |author2=Vassiliki Koufopanou |lastauthoramp=yes |title=The architecture of the life cycle in small organisms |journal=Philosophical Transactions: Biological Sciences |year=1991 |volume=332 |issue=1262 |pages=81–89 |doi=10.1098/rstb.1991.0035}}</ref> Transitions of form may involve growth, [[asexual reproduction]], or [[sexual reproduction]].
In some organisms, different "generations" of the species succeed each other during the life cycle. For [[Embryophyte|plants]] and many [[algae]], there are two multicellular stages, and the life cycle is referred to as [[alternation of generations]]. The term '''life history''' is often used, particularly for organisms such as the [[red algae]] which have three multicellular stages (or more), rather than two.<ref name="Dixon73">Dixon, P.S. 1973. ''Biology of the Rhodophyta.'' Oliver & Boyd. {{ISBN|0 05 002485 X}}</ref>
Life cycles that include sexual reproduction involve alternating [[haploid]] (''n'') and [[diploid]] (2''n'') stages, i.e., a change of [[ploidy]] is involved. To return from a diploid stage to a haploid stage, [[meiosis]] must occur. In regard to changes of [[ploidy]], there are 3 types of cycles: *'''''haplontic''''' life cycle — the haploid stage is multicellular and the diploid stage is a single cell, meiosis is "zygotic". *'''''diplontic''''' life cycle — the diploid stage is multicellular and haploid [[gamete]]s are formed, meiosis is "gametic". *'''''haplodiplontic''''' life cycle (also referred to as ''diplohaplontic'', ''diplobiontic'', or ''dibiontic'' life cycle) — multicellular diploid and haploid stages occur, meiosis is "sporic".
The cycles differ in when [[mitosis]] (growth) occurs. '''Zygotic meiosis''' and '''gametic meiosis''' have one mitotic stage: mitosis occurs during the ''n'' phase in zygotic meiosis and during the 2''n'' phase in gametic meiosis. Therefore, zygotic and gametic meiosis are collectively termed '''haplobiontic''' (single mitotic phase, not to be confused with haplontic). '''Sporic meiosis''', on the other hand, has mitosis in two stages, both the diploid and haploid stages, termed '''diplobiontic''' (not to be confused with diplontic).
==Discovery== The study of [[reproduction]] and [[Embryogenesis|development]] in organisms was carried out by many botanists and zoologists.
[[Wilhelm Hofmeister]] demonstrated that [[alternation of generations]] is a feature that unites plants, and published this result in 1851 (see [[History of botany#Plant sexuality|plant sexuality]]).
Some terms (haplobiont and diplobiont) used for the description of life cycles were proposed initially for algae by Nils Svedelius, and then became used for other organisms.<ref>{{Citation |title=Nils Eberhard Svedelius. 1873-1960 | author=C. Skottsberg | journal=Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society | year=1961 | volume=7 | pages=294–312 | doi=10.1098/rsbm.1961.0023}}</ref><ref>Svedelius, N. 1931. [http://bibdigital.rjb.csic.es/ing/Libro.php?Libro=3629&Pagina=41 Nuclear Phases and Alternation in the Rhodophyceae.] In: ''Beihefte zum Botanischen Centralblatt.'' Band 48/1: 38-59.</ref> Other terms (autogamy and gamontogamy) used in [[protist]] life cycles were introduced by Karl Gottlieb Grell.<ref>{{Citation |title=Archaeal-eubacterial mergers in the origin of Eukarya: phylogenetic classification of life | author=L. Margulis | journal=PNAS | year=1996 | volume=93 | issue=3 | pages=1071–1076 | doi=10.1073/pnas.93.3.1071| pmc=40032 }}</ref> The description of the complex life cycles of various organisms contributed to the disproof of the ideas of [[spontaneous generation]] in the 1840s and 1850s.<ref>Moselio Schaechter (2009). ''Encyclopedia of Microbiology''. Academic Press. Volume 4, p. 85.</ref>
==Haplontic life cycle== [[File:Haploid English.svg|thumb|250px|Zygotic meiosis]] A '''zygotic meiosis''' is a [[meiosis]] of a [[zygote]] immediately after [[karyogamy]], which is the fusion of two [[cell nucleus|cell nuclei]]. This way, the organism ends its diploid phase and produces several haploid cells. These cells divide [[mitotic]]ally to form either larger, multicellular individuals, or more haploid cells. Two opposite types of gametes (e.g., male and female) from these individuals or cells fuse to become a zygote.
In the whole cycle, zygotes are the only diploid cell; mitosis occurs only in the haploid phase.
The individuals or cells as a result of mitosis are '''haplonts''', hence this life cycle is also called '''haplontic life cycle'''. Haplonts are:
* In [[archaeplastida]]ns: some [[green algae]] (e.g., ''[[Chlamydomonas]]'', ''[[Zygnema]]'', ''[[Chara (alga)|Chara]]'')<ref name="Díaz">Díaz González, T.E., C. Fernandez-Carvajal Alvarez & J.A. Fernández Prieto. (2004). ''Curso de Botánica''. Gijón: Trea. Online material: ''[http://www.unioviedo.es/bos/Asignaturas/Botanica/1.htm Botánica: Ciclos biológicos de vegetales]'' (Vegetal life cycles, in Spanish). Departamento de Biología de Organismos y Sistemas, Universidad de Oviedo.</ref> * In [[stramenopiles]]: some [[golden algae]]<ref name="Díaz" /> * In [[alveolate]]s: many [[dinoflagellate]]s eg.Ceratium, Gymnodinium, some [[apicomplexan]]s (e.g., ''[[Plasmodium]]'')<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Sinden | first1 = R. E. | last2 = Hartley | first2 = R. H. | title = Identification of the meiotic division of malarial parasites | journal = The Journal of protozoology | volume = 32 | issue = 4 | pages = 742–744 | year = 1985 | pmid = 3906103 | doi=10.1111/j.1550-7408.1985.tb03113.x }}</ref> * In [[rhizaria]]ns: some [[euglyphid]]s,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lahr DJ, Parfrey LW, Mitchell EA, Katz LA, Lara E |title=The chastity of amoebae: re-evaluating evidence for sex in amoeboid organisms |journal=Proc. Biol. Sci. |volume=278 |issue=1715 |pages=2083–6|date=July 2011 |pmid=21429931 |pmc=3107637 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2011.0289 |url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=21429931}}</ref> [[ascetosporea]]ns * In [[excavate]]s: some [[parabasalid]]s<ref name="Ruppert" /> * In [[amoebozoa]]ns: ''[[Dictyostelium]]''<ref name="Díaz" /> * In [[opisthokont]]s: most [[fungi]] (some [[chytrid]]s, [[zygomycetes]], some [[ascomycetes]], [[basidiomycetes]])<ref name="Díaz" /><ref>van den Hoek, C., D.G. Mann, and H.M. Jahns (1995). ''Algae: an introduction to phycology'', p. 15, [https://books.google.com/books?id=s1P855ZWc0kC&lpg=PR5&hl=&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q&f=false]. Cambridge University Press (623 pp).</ref>
==Diplontic life cycle== [[File:Diploid English.svg|thumb|250px|Gametic meiosis]]
In '''gametic meiosis''', instead of immediately dividing ''meiotically'' to produce haploid cells, the zygote divides ''mitotically'' to produce a multicellular diploid individual or a group of more unicellular diploid cells. Cells from the diploid individuals then undergo meiosis to produce haploid cells or [[gamete]]s. Haploid cells may divide again (by mitosis) to form more haploid cells, as in many yeasts, but the haploid phase is not the predominant life cycle phase. In most diplonts, mitosis occurs only in the diploid phase, i.e. gametes usually form quickly and fuse to produce diploid zygotes.
In the whole cycle, gametes are usually the only haploid cells, and mitosis usually occurs only in the diploid phase.
The diploid multicellular individual is a '''diplont''', hence a gametic meiosis is also called a '''diplontic life cycle'''. Diplonts are:
* In [[archaeplastida]]ns: some [[green algae]] (e.g., ''[[Cladophora|Cladophora glomerata]]'',<ref>O. P. Sharma. Textbook of Algae, p. 189</ref> ''[[Acetabularia]]''<ref name="Díaz" />) * In [[stramenopiles]]: some [[brown algae]] (the [[Fucales]], however, their life cycle can also be interpreted as strongly heteromorphic-diplohaplontic, with a highly reduced gametophyte phase, as in the [[flowering plants]]),<ref>van den Hoek, C. et al. (1995), p. 207, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xuUoiFesSHMC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA207#v=onepage&q&f=false].</ref> some [[xanthophyte]]s (e.g., ''[[Vaucheria]]''),<ref>van den Hoek, C. et al. (1995), pp. 124, 129.</ref> most [[diatom]]s,<ref name="Ruppert" /> some [[oomycete]]s (e.g., ''[[Saprolegnia]]'', ''[[Plasmopara viticola]]''),<ref name="Díaz" /> [[opaline]]s,<ref name="Ruppert">Ruppert, E. E., Fox, R. S., & Barnes, R. D. (2004). ''Invertebrate zoology: a functional evolutionary approach''. Belmont, CA: Thomas-Brooks/Cole, p.26.</ref> some "[[heliozoan]]s" (e.g., ''[[Actinophrys]]'', ''[[Actinosphaerium]]'')<ref name="Ruppert" /><ref>Bell, G. (1989). ''Sex and Death in Protozoa''. Cambridge University Press, p. 11, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0lCengzqXfsC&lpg=PP1&hl=&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false].</ref> * In [[alveolate]]s: [[ciliate]]s <ref name="Ruppert" /> * In [[excavate]]s: some [[parabasalid]]s <ref name="Ruppert" /> * In [[opisthokont]]s: [[animal]]s, some [[fungi]] (e.g., some [[ascomycetes]])<ref name="Díaz" />
==Haplodiplontic life cycle== [[File:Diplohaplontic English.svg|thumb|250px|Sporic meiosis]] {{Main|Alternation of generations}} In '''sporic meiosis''' (also commonly known as '''intermediary meiosis'''), the zygote divides mitotically to produce a multicellular diploid [[sporophyte]]. The sporophyte creates spores via meiosis which ''also'' then divide mitotically producing haploid individuals called [[gametophyte]]s. The gametophytes produce gametes via mitosis. In some plants the gametophyte is not only small-sized but also short-lived; in other plants and many algae, the gametophyte is the "dominant" stage of the life cycle.
Haplodiplonts are:
* In [[archaeplastida]]ns: [[red algae]] (which have two sporophyte generations), some [[green algae]] (e.g., ''[[Ulva (genus)|Ulva]]''), [[Embryophyte|land plants]]<ref name="Díaz" /> * In [[stramenopiles]]: most [[brown algae]]<ref name="Díaz" /> * In [[rhizaria]]ns: many [[foraminiferan]]s,<ref name="Ruppert" /> [[plasmodiophoromycetes]]<ref name="Díaz" /> * In [[amoebozoa]]: [[myxogastrid]]s * In [[opisthokont]]s: some [[fungi]] (some [[chytrid]]s, some [[ascomycetes]] like the [[brewer's yeast]])<ref name="Díaz" /> * Other eukaryotes: [[haptophyte]]s<ref name="Ruppert" />
Some animals have a [[sex-determination system]] called [[haplodiploid]], but this is not related to the haplodiplontic life cycle.
== Vegetative meiosis == Some [[red algae]] (such as ''Bonnemaisonia''<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/tandf/tejp/2009/00000044/00000003/art00012|title=Somatic meiosis in the life history of Bonnemaisonia asparagoides and Bonnemaisonia clavata (Bonnemaisoniales, Rhodophyta) from the Iberian peninsula|first1=Noemi|last1=Salvador Soler|first2=Amelia|last2=Gomez Garreta|first3=M.|last3=Antonia Ribera Siguan|date=1 August 2009|publisher=|journal=European Journal of Phycology|volume=44|issue=3|pages=381–393|via=IngentaConnect|doi=10.1080/09670260902780782}}</ref> and ''[[Lemanea]]'') and green algae (such as ''[[Prasiola]]'') have '''vegetative meiosis''', also called '''somatic meiosis''', which is a rare phenomenon.<ref>van den Hoek, C. et al. (1995), pp. 82, 453.</ref> Vegetative meiosis can occur in haplodiplontic and also in diplontic life cycles. The gametophytes remain attached to and part of the sporophyte. Vegetative (non-reproductive) diploid cells undergo meiosis, generating vegetative haploid cells. These undergo many mitosis, and produces gametes.
A different phenomenon, called '''vegetative diploidization''', a type of [[apomixis]], occurs in some [[brown alga]]e (e.g., ''Elachista stellaris'').<ref>{{cite journal|author=Lewis, R.J.|year=1996|title=Chromosomes of the brown algae|journal=Phycologia|volume=35|issue=1|pages=19–40|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2216/i0031-8884-35-1-19.1|doi=10.2216/i0031-8884-35-1-19.1}}</ref> Cells in a haploid part of the plant spontaneously duplicate their chromosomes to produce diploid tissue.
==Evolution== The primitive type of life cycle probably had haploid individuals with asexual reproduction.<ref name="Ruppert" /> [[Bacteria]] and [[archaea]] exhibit a life cycle like this, and some eukaryotes apparently do too (e.g., [[Cryptophyta]], [[Choanoflagellata]], many [[Euglenozoa]], many [[Amoebozoa]], some red algae, some [[green algae]], the [[imperfect fungi]], some [[rotifer]]s and many other groups, not necessarily haploid).<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Heywood, P. |author2=Magee, P.T. |year=1976|title=Meiosis in protists. Some structural and physiological aspects of meiosis in algae, fungi, and protozoa|journal=Bacteriological Reviews|volume=40|issue=1|pages=190–240|url=http://mmbr.asm.org/content/40/1/190.short}}</ref> However, these eukaryotes probably are not primitively asexual, but have lost their sexual reproduction, or it just was not observed yet.<ref>{{cite journal |title=An Expanded Inventory of Conserved Meiotic Genes Provides Evidence for Sex in ''Trichomonas vaginalis'' |author1=Shehre-Banoo Malik |author2=Arthur W. Pightling |author3=Lauren M. Stefaniak |author4=Andrew M. Schurko |author5=John M. Logsdon, Jr |last-author-amp=yes |journal=PLoS ONE |year=2008 |volume=3 |issue=8 |pages= e2879 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002879 |pmid=18663385 |pmc=2488364}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Speijer | first1 = D. | last2 = Lukeš | first2 = J. | last3 = Eliáš | first3 = M. | year = 2015 | title = Sex is a ubiquitous, ancient, and inherent attribute of eukaryotic life | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/112/29/8827.short | journal = PNAS | volume = 112 | issue = 29| pages = 8827–8834 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1501725112| pmc = 4517231 }}</ref> Many eukaryotes (including animals and plants) exhibit [[asexual reproduction]], which may be facultative or obligate in the life cycle, with sexual reproduction occurring more or less frequently.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Schön, I. |author2=Martens, K. |author3=van Dijk, P. |year=2009 |title=Lost Sex: The Evolutionary Biology of Parthenogenesis |publisher=Springer|isbn=9789048127702|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GaWD_OtE0AMC}}</ref>

John Tyler Bonner. Princeton University Press, Princeton (New Jersey).] * {{cite journal | last1 = Valero | first1 = M | year = 1992 | title = Evolution of alternation of haploid and diploid phases in life cycles | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/016953479290195H | journal = Trends in Ecology & Evolution | volume = 7 | issue = 1| pages = 25–29 | doi=10.1016/0169-5347(92)90195-h}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Mable | first1 = B. | last2 = Otto | first2 = S. | year = 1998 | title = The evolution of life cycles with haploid and diploid phase | url = http://www.zoology.ubc.ca/~otto/Reprints/Mable1998.pdf | format = PDF | journal = BioEssays | volume = 20 | issue = | pages = 453–462 | doi=10.1002/(sici)1521-1878(199806)20:6<453::aid-bies3>3.0.co;2-n}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/79.18.185.231|79.18.185.231]] ([[User talk:79.18.185.231|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
Clarified that it is not in all cases that enantiomers have different biological effects. Added missing references.
revision.text: {{other uses}} [[Image:Chirality with hands.svg|200px|thumb|Two enantiomers of a generic [[amino acid]] that is '''chiral''']] '''Chirality''' {{IPAc-en|k|aɪ|ˈ|r|æ|l|ɪ|t|iː}} is a property of [[asymmetry]] important in several branches of science. The word ''chirality'' is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|el|χειρ}} (''kheir''), "hand," a familiar chiral object. An object or a system is ''chiral'' if it is distinguishable from its [[mirror image]]; that is, it cannot be [[wikt:superposed|superposed]] onto it. Conversely, a mirror image of an ''achiral'' object, such as a sphere, cannot be distinguished from the object. A chiral object and its mirror image are called ''enantiomorphs'' (Greek, "opposite forms") or, when referring to molecules, ''[[enantiomers]]''. A non-chiral object is called ''achiral'' (sometimes also ''amphichiral'') and can be superposed on its mirror image. If the object is non-chiral and is imagined as being colored blue and its mirror image is imagined as colored yellow, then by a series of rotations and translations the two can be superposed, producing green, with none of the original colors remaining. The term was first used by [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Lord Kelvin]] in 1893 in the second [[Robert Boyle Lecture]] at the [[Oxford University Junior Scientific Club]] which was published in 1894: {{quote|I call any geometrical figure, or group of points, 'chiral', and say that it has chirality if its image in a plane mirror, ideally realized, cannot be brought to coincide with itself.{{cite journal |title=The Molecular Tactics of a Crystal |author=Sir William Thomson Lord Kelvin | year=1894 | publisher=[[Clarendon Press]] | url=https://archive.org/details/moleculartactic00kelvgoog}}}} Human [[hand]]s are perhaps the most universally recognized example of chirality. The left hand is a non-superimposable mirror image of the right hand; no matter how the two hands are oriented, it is impossible for all the major features of both hands to coincide across all axes.Georges Henry Wagnière, ''On Chirality and the Universal Asymmetry: Reflections on Image and Mirror Image'' (2007). This difference in symmetry becomes obvious if someone attempts to shake the right hand of a person using their left hand, or if a left-handed glove is placed on a right hand. In mathematics, ''chirality'' is the property of a figure that is not identical to its mirror image. ==Mathematics== [[File:Orbifold 2X.2.svg|thumb|200px|An achiral 3D object without central symmetry or a plane of symmetry]] [[Image:Knot table.svg|thumb|200px|right|A table of all [[prime knot]]s with seven [[Crossing number (knot theory)|crossings]] or fewer (not including mirror images).]] {{main|Chirality (mathematics)}} In [[mathematics]], a figure is chiral (and said to have chirality) if it cannot be mapped to its mirror image by [[Rotation (mathematics)|rotation]]s and [[Translation (geometry)|translation]]s alone. For example, a right shoe is different from a left shoe, and clockwise is different from anticlockwise. See {{cite journal | author = Petitjean, M. | title = Chirality in metric spaces. In memoriam Michel Deza | journal = Optimization Letters | year = 2017 | doi = 10.1007/s11590-017-1189-7}} for a full mathematical definition. A chiral object and its mirror image are said to be enantiomorphs. The word ''enantiomorph'' stems from the Greek {{lang|grc|ἐναντίος}} (enantios) 'opposite' + {{lang|grc|μορφή}} (morphe) 'form'. A non-chiral figure is called achiral or amphichiral. The [[helix]] (and by extension a spun string, a screw, a propeller, etc.) and [[Möbius strip]] are chiral two-dimensional objects in three-dimensional ambient space. The J, L, S and Z-shaped ''[[tetromino]]es'' of the popular video game [[Tetris]] also exhibit chirality, but only in a two-dimensional space. Many other familiar objects exhibit the same chiral symmetry of the human body, such as gloves, glasses (where two lenses differ in prescription), and shoes. A similar notion of chirality is considered in [[knot theory]], as explained below. Some chiral three-dimensional objects, such as the helix, can be assigned a right or left handedness, according to the [[right-hand rule]]. ===Geometry=== In [[geometry]] a figure is achiral if and only if its [[symmetry group]] contains at least one ''orientation-reversing'' isometry. In two dimensions, every figure that possesses an [[axis of symmetry]] is achiral, and it can be shown that every ''bounded'' achiral figure must have an axis of symmetry. In three dimensions, every figure that possesses a [[plane of symmetry]] or a center of symmetry is achiral. There are, however, achiral figures lacking both plane and center of symmetry. In terms of [[point groups]], all chiral figures lack an improper axis of rotation (Sn). This means that they cannot contain a center of inversion (i) or a mirror plane (σ). Only figures with a point group designation of C1, Cn, Dn, T, O, or I can be chiral. ===Knot theory=== A [[knot (mathematics)|knot]] is called [[amphichiral knot|achiral]] if it can be continuously deformed into its mirror image, otherwise it is called chiral. For example, the [[unknot]] and the [[figure-eight knot (mathematics)|figure-eight knot]] are achiral, whereas the [[trefoil knot]] is chiral. {{clear|both}} ==Physics== [[Image:Circular.Polarization.Circularly.Polarized.Light Right.Handed.Animation.305x190.255Colors.gif|thumb|200px|Animation of left-handed (anticlockwise), [[circularly polarized]], [[light]] as viewed in the direction of the source, in agreement with [[physics]] and [[astronomy]] conventions.]] {{main|Chirality (physics)}} In physics, chirality may be found in the [[Spin (physics)|spin]] of a particle, where the handedness of the object is determined by the direction in which the particle spins.{{cite web|url=http://discovermagazine.com/1995/nov/lookingfortherig591|title=Looking for the Right Hand - DiscoverMagazine.com|author=|date=|website=discovermagazine.com|accessdate=23 March 2018}} Not to be confused with [[Helicity (particle physics)|helicity]], which is the projection of the spin along the linear momentum of a subatomic particle, chirality is a purely quantum mechanical phenomenon like spin. Although both can have left-handed or right-handed properties, only in the massless case do they have a simple relation.{{cite web|url=http://www.quantumdiaries.org/2011/06/19/helicity-chirality-mass-and-the-higgs/|title=Quantum Diaries|author=|date=|website=www.quantumdiaries.org|accessdate=23 March 2018}} In particular for a massless particle the helicity is the same as the chirality while for an antiparticle they have opposite sign. The ''handedness'' in both chirality and helicity relate to the rotation of a particle while it proceeds in linear motion with reference to the human hands. The thumb of the hand points towards the direction of linear motion whilst the fingers curl into the palm, representing the direction of rotation of the particle (i.e. clockwise and counterclockwise). Depending on the linear and rotational motion, the particle can either be defined by left-handedness (ex. translating leftwards and rotating counterclockwise) or right-handedness (ex. translating in the right direction and rotating clockwise). A symmetry transformation between the two is called [[parity (physics)|parity]]. Invariance under parity by a [[Dirac fermion]] is called ''chiral symmetry''. ===Electromagnetism=== {{main|Chirality (electromagnetism)}} [[Electromagnetic radiation|Electromagnetic]] wave [[Wave propagation|propagation]] as [[handedness]] is wave [[Polarization (waves)|polarization]] and described in terms of [[Circular dichroism|helicity]] (occurs as a helix). Polarization of an [[electromagnetic wave]] is the property that describes the [[Orientation (geometry)|orientation]], i.e., the [[periodic function|time-varying]], direction ([[Euclidean vector|vector]]), and [[amplitude]] of the [[electric field]] vector. For a depiction, see the adjacent image. ==Chemistry== [[File:Zwitterion-Alanine.png|thumb|right|200px|(''S'')-Alanine (left) and (''R'')-alanine (right) in zwitterionic form at neutral pH]] {{main|Chirality (chemistry)}} A ''chiral molecule'' is a type of [[molecule]] that has a non-superposable [[mirror image]]. The feature that is most often the cause of chirality in molecules is the presence of an [[asymmetric carbon|asymmetric carbon atom]].''Organic Chemistry'' (4th Edition) Paula Y. Bruice.''Organic Chemistry'' (3rd Edition) Marye Anne Fox, James K. Whitesell. The term "chiral" in general is used to describe the object that is non-superposable on its mirror image.{{GoldBookRef|title=chirality|file=C01058}} In chemistry, chirality usually refers to molecules. Two mirror images of a chiral molecule are called [[enantiomer]]s or optical [[isomer]]s. Pairs of enantiomers are often designated as "[[right-handed|right-]]", "left-handed" or if it has no bias achiral. As polarized light passes through a chiral molecule, the plane of polarization, when viewed along the axis toward the source, will be rotated in a clockwise (to the right) or anticlockwise (to the left). A right handed rotation is dextrorotary (d); that to the left is levorotary (l). The d- and l-isomers are the same compound but are called [[enantiomers]]. An equimolar mixture of the two optical isomers will produce no net rotation of polarized light as it passes through.{{cite book|last1=Chang|first1=Raymond|title=Chemistry|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=0-394-32983-X|page=660|edition=second}} Left handed molecules have l- prefixed to their names; d- is prefixed to right handed molecules. Molecular chirality is of interest because of its application to [[stereochemistry]] in [[inorganic chemistry]], [[organic chemistry]], [[physical chemistry]], [[biochemistry]], and [[supramolecular chemistry]]. More recent developments in chiral chemistry include the development of chiral inorganic nanoparticles that may have the similar tetrahedral geometry as chiral centers associated with sp3 carbon atoms traditionally associated with chiral compounds, but at larger scale.{{Cite journal|last=Moloney|first=Mícheál P.|last2=Gun'ko|first2=Yurii K.|last3=Kelly|first3=John M.|date=2007-09-26|title=Chiral highly luminescent CdS quantum dots|url=https://doi.org/10.1039/b704636g|journal=Chemical Communications|language=en|volume=0|issue=38|doi=10.1039/b704636g|issn=1364-548X}}{{Cite journal|last=Schaaff|first=T.
