Gregory|last2=Knight|first2=Grady|last3=Shafigullin|first3=Marat N.|last4=Borkman|first4=Raymond F.|last5=Whetten|first5=Robert L.|date=1998-12-01|title=Isolation and Selected Properties of a 10.4 kDa Gold:Glutathione Cluster Compound|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jp9830528|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|volume=102|issue=52|pages=10643–10646|doi=10.1021/jp9830528|issn=1520-6106}} Helical and other symmetries of chiral nanomaterials were also obtained.{{Cite journal|last=Ma|first=Wei|last2=Xu|first2=Liguang|last3=de Moura|first3=André F.|last4=Wu|first4=Xiaoling|last5=Kuang|first5=Hua|last6=Xu|first6=Chuanlai|last7=Kotov|first7=Nicholas A.|date=2017-06-28|title=Chiral Inorganic Nanostructures|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00755|journal=Chemical Reviews|volume=117|issue=12|pages=8041–8093|doi=10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00755|issn=0009-2665}} ==Biology== {{See also|Homochirality}} All of the known life-forms show specific chiral properties in chemical structures as well as macroscopic anatomy, development and behavior.{{Cite journal|last=Xiao|first=Wende|last2=Ernst|first2=Karl-Heinz|last3=Palotas|first3=Krisztian|last4=Zhang|first4=Yuyang|last5=Bruyer|first5=Emilie|last6=Peng|first6=Lingqing|last7=Greber|first7=Thomas|last8=Hofer|first8=Werner A.|last9=Scott|first9=Lawrence T.|date=2016-02-08|title=Microscopic origin of chiral shape induction in achiral crystals|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nchem.2449|journal=Nature Chemistry|language=En|volume=8|issue=4|pages=326–330|doi=10.1038/nchem.2449|issn=1755-4330}} In any specific organism or evolutionarily related set thereof, individual compounds, organs, or behavior are found in the same single enantiomorphic form. Deviation (having the opposite form) could be found in a small number of chemical compounds, or certain organ or behavior but that variation strictly depends upon the genetic make up of the organism. From chemical level (molecular scale), biological systems show extreme stereospecificity in synthesis, uptake, sensing, metabolic processing. A living system usually deals with two enantiomers of same compound in a drastically different way. In biology, homochirality is a common property of [[Amino acid#Isomerism|amino acids]] and [[Monosaccharide#Open-chain stereoisomers|carbohydrates]]. The chiral [[Proteinogenic amino acid|protein-making amino acids]], which are translated through the ribosome from genetic coding, occur in the L form. However, D-amino acids are also found in nature. The monosaccharides (carbohydrate-units) are commonly found in D-configuration. DNA double helix is chiral (as any kind of [[Helix#Types|helix]] is chiral), and [[B-DNA|B-form of DNA]] shows a right-handed turn. {{multiple image |image1 = R-Limonene.png |width1 = 75 |caption1 = ''R''-(+)-Limonene found in orange |image2 = S-Limonene.png |width2 = 75 |caption2 = ''S''-(–)-Limonene found in lemon }} Sometimes, when two enantiomers of a compound found in organisms, they significantly differ in their taste, smell and other biological actions. For example, (+)-Limonene found in orange (causing its smell), and (–)-Limonene found in Lemons (causing its smell), show different smellsSolomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), Section 5.5 More about biological significance of chirality due to different biochemical interactions at human nose. (+)-Carvone is responsible for the smell of [[Caraway]] seed oil whereas (–)-carvone is responsible for smell of [[Spearmint]] oil.Solomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), review problem 5.14 [[File:Carvone-enantiomers1.jpg|thumb|S-(+)-Carvone occurs in Caraway seed oil, and R-(-)-Carvone occurs in spearmint|296x296px]] {{multiple image |image1 = Dextropropoxyphene structure.svg |width1 = 200 |caption1 = Dextropropoxyphene or Darvon, a painkiller |image2 = Levopropoxyphene structure.svg |width2 = 200 |caption2 = Levopropoxyphene or Novrad, an anticough agent }} Also, for artificial compounds, including medicines, in case of chiral drugs, the two enantiomers sometimes show remarkable difference in effect of their biological actions.{{Cite journal|last=Sanganyado|first=Edmond|last2=Lu|first2=Zhijiang|last3=Fu|first3=Qiuguo|last4=Schlenk|first4=Daniel|last5=Gan|first5=Jay|date=2017|title=Chiral pharmaceuticals: A review on their environmental occurrence and fate processes|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0043135417306565|journal=Water Research|volume=124|pages=527–542|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2017.08.003|issn=0043-1354|via=}} Darvon ([[Dextropropoxyphene]]) is a painkiller, whereas its enantiomer, Novrad ([[Levopropoxyphene]]) is an anti-cough agent. In case of [[Penicillamine]], the S-isomer used in treatment of primary chronic arthritis, Whereas the R-isomer has no therapeutic effect as well as being highly toxic.Solomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), section 5.11(chiral drugs) In some cases the less therapeutically active enantiomer can cause side effects. For example, S-naproxen is an analgesic but the R-isomer cause renal problems.{{Cite journal|last=Suzuki|first=Toshinari|last2=Kosugi|first2=Yuki|last3=Hosaka|first3=Mitsugu|last4=Nishimura|first4=Tetsuji|last5=Nakae|first5=Dai|date=2014-10-08|title=Occurrence and behavior of the chiral anti-inflammatory drug naproxen in an aquatic environment|url=https://setac.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/etc.2741|journal=Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry|language=en|volume=33|issue=12|pages=2671–2678|doi=10.1002/etc.2741|issn=0730-7268}} The naturally occurring plant form of alpha-tocopherol ([[vitamin E]]) is RRR-α-tocopherol whereas the synthetic form (all-racemic vitamin E, or dl-tocopherol) is equal parts of the stereoisomers RRR, RRS, RSS, SSS, RSR, SRS, SRR and SSR with progressively decreasing biological equivalency, so that 1.36 mg of dl-tocopherol is considered equivalent to 1.0 mg of d-tocopherol.{{cite journal |vauthors=Manolescu B, Atanasiu V, Cercasov C, Stoian I, Oprea E, Buşu C |title=So many options but one choice: the human body prefers alpha-tocopherol. A matter of stereochemistry |journal=J Med Life |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=376–382 |date=2008 |pmid=20108516 |pmc=5654212 |doi= |url=}} [[File:DirkvdM natural spiral.jpg|thumb|A natural left-handed helix, made by a certain climber plant's [[tendril]]. |171x171px]] Macroscopic example of Chirality is found in plant kingdom, animal kingdom and all other groups of organism. A simple example is the coiling direction of any climber plants. It may be one of two possible type of helix. [[File:Neptunea - links&rechts gewonden.jpg|thumb|200px|Shells of two different species of sea snail: on the left is the normally sinistral (left-handed) shell of ''[[Neptunea angulata]]'', on the right is the normally dextral (right-handed) shell of ''[[Neptunea despecta]]'']] In anatomy, chirality is found in the imperfect mirror image symmetry of many kinds of animal bodies. Organisms such as [[gastropod]]s exhibit chirality in their coiled shells, resulting in an asymmetrical appearance. Over 90% of gastropod species {{cite journal | last1 = Schilthuizen | first1 = M. | last2 = Davison | first2 = A. | year = 2005 | title = The convoluted evolution of snail chirality | url = | journal = [[Naturwissenschaften]] | volume = 92 | issue = 11| pages = 504–515 | doi = 10.1007/s00114-05-0045-2| bibcode = 2005NW.....92..504S }} have ''dextral'' (right-handed) shells in their coiling, but a small minority of species and genera are virtually always ''sinistral'' (left-handed). A very few species (for example ''[[Amphidromus perversus]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.jaxshells.org/052ddr.htm|title=Amphidromus perversus (Linnaeus, 1758)|author=|date=|website=www.jaxshells.org|accessdate=23 March 2018}}) show an equal mixture of dextral and sinistral individuals. In humans, chirality (also referred to as ''handedness'' or ''laterality'') is an attribute of humans defined by their unequal distribution of [[fine motor skill]] between the left and right [[hands]]. An individual who is more [[Dexterity|dexterous]] with the right hand is called ''[[right-handed]]'', and one who is more skilled with the left is said to be ''[[left-handed]]''. Chirality is also seen in the study of [[facial asymmetry]]. In flatfish, the [[Summer flounder]] or fluke are left-eyed, while [[halibut]] are right-eyed. ==See also== * [[Asymmetry]] * [[Handedness]] * [[Metachirality]] * [[Orientation (mathematics)]] * [[Right-hand rule]] * [[Sinistral and dextral]] * [[Stereochemistry]] * [[Tendril perversion]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * The Handedness of the Universe by Roger A Hegstrom and Dilip K Kondepudi http://quantummechanics.ucsd.edu/ph87/ScientificAmerican/Sciam/Hegstrom_The_Handedness_of_the_universe.pdf {{Wiktionary}} {{Navbox stereochemistry}} [[Category:Biochemistry]] [[Category:Life]] [[Category:Origin of life]] [[Category:Stereochemistry]] [[Category:Chirality| ]] [[Category:Pharmacology]]

revision.comment: If viewed as a bracelet, which is not the same object as a necklace, the middle one is chiral.
revision.text:
[[File:2 parallel footprints.png|thumb|Individual left and right footprints are chiral '''enantiomorphs''' in a plane because they are mirror images while containing no mirror symmetry individually.]] In [[geometry]], a figure is '''chiral''' (and said to have '''chirality''') if it is not identical to its [[mirror image]], or, more precisely, if it cannot be mapped to its mirror image by [[Rotation (mathematics)|rotation]]s and [[Translation (geometry)|translation]]s alone. An object that is not chiral is said to be achiral. In 3 dimensions, not all achiral objects have a mirror plane. For example, a 3-dimensional object with [[inversion centre]] as its only nontrivial [[symmetry operation]] is achiral but has no mirror plane.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} A chiral object and its mirror image are said to be '''enantiomorphs'''. The word ''chirality'' is derived from the Greek {{lang|grc|χείρ}} (cheir), the hand, the most familiar chiral object; the word ''enantiomorph'' stems from the Greek {{lang|grc|ἐναντίος}} (enantios) 'opposite' + {{lang|grc|μορφή}} (morphe) 'form'. A non-chiral figure is called '''achiral''' or '''amphichiral'''. == Examples== [[File:3D Cartesian Coodinate Handedness.jpg|thumb|left|Left and [[right-hand rule]]s in three dimensions]] {| class=wikitable align=right |+ The [[tetromino]]s S and Z are enantiomorphs in 2-dimensions ![[File:Tetromino S.svg|100px]]
S ![[File:Tetromino Z.svg|94px]]
Z |} Some chiral three-dimensional objects, such as the [[helix]], can be assigned a right or left [[handedness]], according to the [[right-hand rule]]. Many other familiar objects exhibit the same chiral symmetry of the human body, such as gloves and shoes. Right shoes differ from left shoes only by being mirror images of each other. In contrast thin gloves may not be considered chiral if you can wear them [[wiktionary:inside out|inside-out]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} The J, L, S and Z-shaped ''[[tetromino]]es'' of the popular video game [[Tetris]] also exhibit chirality, but only in a two-dimensional space. Individually they contain no mirror symmetry in the plane. ==Chirality and symmetry group== A figure is achiral if and only if its [[symmetry group]] contains at least one ''orientation-reversing'' isometry. (In Euclidean geometry any [[isometry]] can be written as v\mapsto Av+b with an [[orthogonal matrix]] A and a vector b. The [[determinant]] of A is either 1 or −1 then. If it is −1 the isometry is ''[[orientation (mathematics)|orientation]]-reversing'', otherwise it is orientation-preserving.) See {{cite journal | author = Petitjean, M. | title = Chirality in metric spaces. In memoriam Michel Deza | journal = Optimization Letters | year = 2017 | doi = 10.1007/s11590-017-1189-7}} for a full mathematical definition of chirality. ==Chirality in three dimensions== [[File:Chiralität von Würfeln V.1.svg|thumb|Pair of chiral [[dice]] (enantiomorphs)]] In three dimensions, every figure that possesses a [[mirror plane of symmetry]] ''S1'', an inversion center of symmetry ''S2'', or a higher [[improper rotation]] (rotoreflection) ''Sn'' axis of symmetry{{cite web|title=2. Symmetry operations and symmetry elements|url=http://chemwiki.ucdavis.edu/Theoretical_Chemistry/Symmetry/Symmetry_operations_and_symmetry_elements|website=chemwiki.ucdavis.edu|accessdate=25 March 2016}} is achiral. (A ''plane of symmetry'' of a figure F is a plane P, such that F is invariant under the mapping (x,y,z)\mapsto(x,y,-z), when P is chosen to be the x-y-plane of the coordinate system. A ''center of symmetry'' of a figure F is a point C, such that F is invariant under the mapping (x,y,z)\mapsto(-x,-y,-z), when C is chosen to be the origin of the coordinate system.) Note, however, that there are achiral figures lacking both plane and center of symmetry. An example is the figure :F_0=\left\{(1,0,0),(0,1,0),(-1,0,0),(0,-1,0),(2,1,1),(-1,2,-1),(-2,-1,1),(1,-2,-1)\right\} which is invariant under the orientation reversing isometry (x,y,z)\mapsto(-y,x,-z) and thus achiral, but it has neither plane nor center of symmetry. The figure :F_1=\left\{(1,0,0),(-1,0,0),(0,2,0),(0,-2,0),(1,1,1),(-1,-1,-1)\right\} also is achiral as the origin is a center of symmetry, but it lacks a plane of symmetry. Note also that achiral figures can have a [[Point groups in three dimensions#Center of symmetry|center axis]]. ==Chirality in two dimensions== [[File:Bracelets33.svg|thumb|300px|The colored [[Necklace (combinatorics)|necklace]] in the middle is '''chiral''' in 2-dimensions, the two others are '''achiral'''.
This means that as physical necklaces on a table the left and right one could be rotated into their mirror image while remaining on the table. The one in the middle, however, would have to be picked up and turned in three dimensions.]] In two dimensions, every figure which possesses an [[axis of symmetry]] is achiral, and it can be shown that every ''bounded'' achiral figure must have an axis of symmetry. (An ''axis of symmetry'' of a figure F is a line L, such that F is invariant under the mapping (x,y)\mapsto(x,-y), when L is chosen to be the x-axis of the coordinate system.) For that reason, a [[triangle]] is achiral if it is [[equilateral triangle|equilateral]] or [[isosceles triangle|isosceles]], and is chiral if it is scalene. Consider the following pattern: :[[File:Krok 6.png|320px]] This figure is chiral, as it is not identical to its mirror image: :[[File:Krok 6 mirrored.png|320px]] But if one prolongs the pattern in both directions to infinity, one receives an (unbounded) achiral figure which has no axis of symmetry. Its symmetry group is a [[frieze group]] generated by a single [[glide reflection]]. ==Knot theory== A [[knot (mathematics)|knot]] is called [[amphichiral knot|achiral]] if it can be continuously deformed into its mirror image, otherwise it is called a [[chiral knot]]. For example, the [[unknot]] and the [[figure-eight knot (mathematics)|figure-eight knot]] are achiral, whereas the [[trefoil knot]] is chiral. ==See also== * [[Chiral polytope]] * [[Chirality (physics)]] * [[Chirality (chemistry)]] * [[Asymmetry]] * [[Skewness]] * [[Vertex algebra]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://petitjeanmichel.free.fr/itoweb.petitjean.html The Mathematical Theory of Chirality] by Michel Petitjean *[http://petitjeanmichel.free.fr/itoweb.petitjean.symmetry.html Symmetry, Chirality, Symmetry Measures and Chirality Measures:] General Definitions * [http://demonstrations.wolfram.com/ChiralPolyhedra/ Chiral Polyhedra] by [[Eric W. Weisstein]], [[The Wolfram Demonstrations Project]]. * [http://www.cambridge.org/us/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521664820 When Topology Meets Chemistry] by [[Erica Flapan]]. *[http://www.map.mpim-bonn.mpg.de/Chiral_manifold Chiral manifold] at the Manifold Atlas. [[Category:Knot theory]] [[Category:Polyhedra]] [[Category:Chirality]] [[Category:Topology]]

revision.comment: /* Creatures */
revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox video game series | title = Creatures | image = Creatures logo.png | platforms = [[Windows]], [[Classic Mac OS]], [[Linux]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]], [[Game Boy Advance]] | platform of origin = Windows, Classic Mac OS | year of inception = 1996 | developer = Creature Labs | publisher = [[Mindscape]] | genre = [[Life simulation game|Life simulation]] | creator = [[Steve Grand (roboticist)|Steve Grand]] }} '''''Creatures''''' is an [[artificial life]] (alife) [[computer program]] series, created in the mid-1990s by English [[computer science|computer scientist]] [[Steve Grand (roboticist)|Steve Grand]] whilst working for the [[Cambridge]] [[video game]]s developer [[Millennium Interactive]]. Gameplay focuses on raising alien creatures known as Norns, teaching them to survive, helping them explore their world, defending them against other species, and breeding them. Words can be taught to creatures by a learning computer (for verbs) or by repeating the name of the object while the creature is looking at it. After a creature understands language, the player can instruct their creature by typing in instructions, which the creature may choose to obey. A complete life cycle is modelled for the creatures - childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and senescence, each with their own particular needs. The gameplay is designed to foster an emotional bond between the player and their creatures. Rather than taking a scripted approach, Creatures series games were driven by detailed biological and neurological simulation and their unexpected results. There were six major Creatures releases from Creature Labs. Between 1996 and 2001, there were three principal games released, the Docking Station add-on (generally referenced as a separate game) and two children's games, and there were three games created for console systems. A sequel named ''Creatures Online'' was in development, with the artificial life technology from Creatures 3 and Docking Station updated to a 3D environment.
==Overview== The program was one of the first commercial titles<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:_vZ4O4mLERcJ:citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi%3D10.1.1.100.8744%26rep%3Drep1%26type%3Dpdf+LINDSEY+HOLT+critical+study+norn&hl=en&gl=au&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESiKpW-yllagk-uKO8f_wsWCvWM6bdgk1t6w98DE37FIVUQbXlROparPfOmv7XaQVzAW0erovrENwZ4Vy6W_1qs8RxNEAIIcogHKOe91zOc_MMju5bd-XlxuYAWmlzSIf-wa085O&sig=AHIEtbReVlSOKkmed7IZEXgADpkhJrVtiA |title=Simulation: Life Inside the Machine |author=Holt, Lindsey |publisher=Docs.google.com |date=2006 |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref> to code [[artificial life|alife]] organisms from the genetic level upwards using a sophisticated [[biochemistry]] and [[neural network]] [[brain]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://utdallas.edu/~maz031000/res/IEEE_Article.pdf |title=Serious Games for Immersive Cultural Training: Creating a Living World |publisher= |work=IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications |date=March–April 2009 |accessdate=2012-10-22 |authors=Marjorie A. Zielke, Monica J. Evans|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.aaai.org/Papers/Symposia/Spring/1999/SS-99-02/SS99-02-017.pdf |title=AI Beyond Computer Games |author=Stern, Andrew |publisher=[[Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence|AAAI]] Technical Report SS-99-02. |year=1999 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> including simulated senses of sight, hearing and touch.<ref name=GrandCliffAAMAS/> This meant that the Norns and their [[DNA]] could develop and "[[evolution|evolve]]" in increasingly diverse ways, unpredicted by the makers. By [[selective breeding|breeding]] certain Norns with others, some traits could be passed on to following generations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/jul/21/business/fi-14868 |title='Creatures' Craze Is Now the Norn - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=1997-07-21 |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref> The Norns turned out to behave similarly to living creatures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agent.ai/doc/upload/200302/tayl97.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029194858/http://www.agent.ai/doc/upload/200302/tayl97.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-10-29 |title=Three ways to get A-life |publisher= |date=July–August 1997 |accessdate=2012-10-22 |work=IEEE EXPERT}}</ref> Sight is simulated by having a group of neurons representing each type of object in the world. When an object belonging to this type is in front of the creature ('within eyesight'), the neuron becomes active and the creature can 'see' the object.<ref name=GrandCliffAAMAS/> The Norns possess simulated [[drive theory|biological drives]] which give punishment when they are raised, and reward when they are lowered. The model for Norns' decision-making process is [[Behaviorist]] and based on Norns learning how to reduce their drives.<ref name="autogenerated1996"/> Dickinson and Balleine state that while this stimulus-response/reinforcement process makes the creatures seem like they are goal-directed, they are instead 'habit machines' responding in a learned fashion to particular stimuli.<ref>{{cite book|title=The evolution of cognition.Vienna series in theoretical biology |year=2000|publisher=The MIT Press|location=Cambridge, MA, US|isbn=978-0262082860|page=186 |author1=Dickinson, Anthony |author2=Balleine, Bernard W. |editor1=Heyes, Cecilia |editor2=Huber, Ludwig |chapter=Causal cognition and goal-directed action.}}</ref>
Mutations in the genome also occur, allowing new characteristics to appear in the population and potentially be inherited by a future generation.<ref name="NGen23">{{cite magazine |last=|first= |title=Millennium Interactive|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=23 |publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=November 1996|pages=56-57}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Woodcock|first=Steven|title=Game AI: The State of the Industry |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131705/game_ai_the_state_of_the_industry.php?page=2|publisher=Gamasutra |date=20 November 1998 }}</ref> Because the Norns have a lifespan of roughly 40 hours, users could observe the changes that occur over a large number of generations.<ref name="NGen23"/> Faulty genomes can also occur - for example, Norns which cannot see or hear,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://partners.nytimes.com/library/cyber/week/060597creatures.html |title=Coming Soon to the Virtual Pet Store: 'Creatures' Who Live, Eat and Reproduce |author=Richtel, Matt |publisher=Partners.nytimes.com |date=June 5, 1997 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> or immortal Norns due to a hyper-efficient digestion system.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971016000846/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july2.htm |url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july2.htm |title=Creatures July Newsletter Page 2 |publisher=Cyberlife |archivedate=1997-10-16 |accessdate=2012-12-12}}</ref><ref name=TCGDE/> Creatures used the [[emergence|emergent]] approach seen in [[animat]]s, but with the goal of more complex behaviours than [[Animal locomotion|locomotion]].<ref name="grand352">{{cite book|last=Grand|first=Steve|title=Human cognition and social agent technology|year=2000 |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9027251398|page=352 |editor=Dautenhahn, Kerstin|chapter=The Emergence of Personality: How to Create Souls from Cells}}</ref> Grand describes the psychological model of the creatures as being inspired by rats.<ref name="Dr.Frankenstein">{{cite journal|journal=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|date=November 1997|title=The game industry's Dr. Frankenstein|pages=8–13}}</ref> In 2000, Steve Grand described the intelligence level of Norns as being like ants.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Graham-Rowe|first=D.|title=God of the Norns|url=https://www.newscientist.com/nl/0401/stephengrand.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000605223245/http://www.newscientist.com/nl/0401/stephengrand.html|archivedate=2000-06-05|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=2000-04-01|volume=165|issue=2232|pages=42–45}}</ref> Margaret Boden, in 2003, rejected ''Creatures'' as being a form of alien life as the simulated metabolism is concerned with controlling the Norn's behaviour, not on maintaining its 'physical' form.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Boden|first=Margaret A.|title=Alien life: how would we know?|journal=International Journal of Astrobiology|year=2003|volume=2|issue=2|pages=121–129 |doi=10.1017/S1473550403001496|bibcode=2003IJAsB...2..121B}}</ref> In 2011, Steve Grand stated that while the Norns in ''Creatures'' could learn, generalise from past experiences to novel experiences, and react in an intelligent manner to stimuli, they could not think.<ref>{{cite web|author=Grand, Steve |url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/2011/03/06/introduction-to-an-artificial-mind/ |title=Introduction to an artificial mind |publisher=Steve Grand's Blog |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
The [[genetics]] in ''Creatures'' are somewhat different from [[physical anthropology|human genetics]]; they are [[haploid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_genetics_preview_kit2.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19980126091513/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_genetics_preview_kit2.htm |archivedate=1998-01-26 |title=GENETICS PREVIEW KIT - REFERENCE GUIDE |publisher=Cyberlife |date=1998-01-26 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> There is no concept of [[dominant gene]] and [[recessive gene]], much less [[Genetic recombination|recombination]] between [[locus (genetics)|loci]]. Nevertheless, the complexity of the simulated biochemistry meant that Norn behaviour was highly unpredictable.
Among the fans of ''Creatures'' were the [[Oxford]] [[zoology|zoologist]] [[Richard Dawkins]], who called it a "quantum leap in the development of artificial life",<ref>{{cite web|title=Creature Labs Archive |url=http://www.peninsulafilms.com/creaturelabsarch.html |work=Peninsula Films |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425092232/http://www.peninsulafilms.com/creaturelabsarch.html |archivedate=April 25, 2012 }}</ref> and author [[Douglas Adams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/106-2/ |title=My books « Steve Grand's Blog |author=Grand, Steve |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> ''Creatures'' inspired some players to take up careers in the sciences.<ref>{{cite web|author=Grand, Steve |url=http://stevegrand.wordpress.com/2011/02/28/blowing-my-own-trumpet/ |title=Blowing my own trumpet |publisher=Steve Grand's Blog |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
==History== Originally conceived as a [[desktop pet]] with a brain,<ref name=initialpitch>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/initialpitch.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312005250/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/initialpitch.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |title=Mouse for Windows |author=Grand, Steve |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=November 4, 1992 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Grand later incorporated inspiration from [[The Planiverse]] to pitch a "little computer [[ewok]]s" game,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/ewokspitch.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312005140/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/ewokspitch.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |author=Grand, Steve |title=Little Computer Ewoks |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=16 November 1992 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> like the game ''[[Little Computer People]]''.<ref name=rationale>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/rationale.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050312012947/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/rationale.htm |archivedate=2005-03-12 |author=Grand, Steve |title=Rationale |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=12 December 1993 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Grand wanted players to have a rapport with their creatures, feeling that he should make the creatures seem "genuinely alive" to the player, showing "the 'right' kind of behaviour' in a variety of circumstances. To create this kind of behaviour, Grand felt it was necessary to program the creatures by simulating the building blocks of nature in a [[Top-down and bottom-up design|bottom-up]] approach, allowing the complex behaviour to [[Emergence|emerge]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Grand|first=Steve|title=Human cognition and social agent technology|year=2000|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9027251398|page=350|editor=Dautenhahn, Kerstin|chapter=The Emergence of Personality: How to Create Souls from Cells}}</ref> rather than using a [[rule-based system]] approach.<ref name="Dr.Frankenstein"/> Grand later wished to include references to an "English" or Norse mythology, to try to make the world more internally consistent,<ref name=mainhistory>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/creatures_history.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081028181218/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/creatures_history.htm |archivedate=2008-10-28 |title=Creatures history |author=Grand, Steve |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=2004-06-04 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref name=mythography>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/mythography.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927203124/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/mythography.htm |archivedate=2008-09-27 |title=Small Furry Creatures: A Mythography |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=8 March 1993 |author=Grand, Steve |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> but found that the team wanted to make the game into a conventional adventure game.<ref name=rationale/> He later decided to scale back on the mythology aspects of the game, focusing instead on the [[artificial life]] point - eventually presenting the game as an artificial [[animal fancy|pet hobby]], which provided some of the impetus to include genetics in the creatures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/pleasureprofit.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927203129/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/pleasureprofit.htm |archivedate=2008-09-27 |author=Grand, Steve |title="Breeding Norns for Pleasure and Profit" — some thoughts |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=1 June 1995 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> ''Creatures'' was developed as a consumer product by [[Millennium Interactive|Millennium]], and was released by [[Mindscape Group|Mindscape]] in 1996. The program was instantly successful,{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} and an [[online community]] of players soon formed, swapping Norns, creating new objects for Albia,<ref name="Jepsen C2"/> sharing tips on how to play the game and anecdotes about unexpected evolutionary changes that they had seen, and even creating new [[Selective breeding|breeds]] of Norn. At one point, the Creatures online community was the largest of its type.
In 1996, ''Creatures'' won an EMMA Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=1996 |title=1996 Winners |publisher=The International EMMA Awards |date=2000-11-21 |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010420074653/http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=1996 |archivedate=2001-04-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/cyberlife_awards2.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970607011020/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/cyberlife_awards2.htm |archivedate=1997-06-07 |title=CREATURES WINS INTERNATIONAL EMMA AWARD |publisher=cyberlife.co.uk |date=1997-06-07 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> Based on sales of 500,000 copies of ''Creatures'' from 1996 through to the second quarter of 1998, it was estimated that at that time, there was a possible global population of up to five million norns.<ref name=TCGDE/>
Development of ''[[Creatures 2]]'' began in Q3 1997.<ref name="Gamasutra C2"/> In 1998, the video games division of [[Millennium Interactive|Millennium]] was sold to Sony Entertainment while those working on alife and ''Creatures'' formed a new company called Cyberlife Technology. Along with continued work on the ''Creatures'' titles, the company did work for industry and the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|British Ministry of Defence]], famously attempting to teach live organisms to fly virtual [[fighter jet]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/ns/980509/features.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990117012705/http://www.newscientist.com/ns/980509/features.html |archivedate=1999-01-17 |title=New Scientist Planet Science: Agents from Albia |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |date=1999-01-17 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stanford.edu/class/sts145/Library/richard.pdf |title=Norn Attacks and Marine Doom |publisher= |author=BIRGIT RICHARD |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> ''Creatures 2'' was nominated in the Artificial Intelligence category of the [[Game Developers Conference]]'s Spotlight Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/Newstand/newsletters/ns_news_stuff_current.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010211202533/http://www.creatures.co.uk/Newstand/newsletters/ns_news_stuff_current.htm |title=Stuff&NORNsense |publisher=Creatures.co.uk |archivedate=2001-02-11 |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref>
In the late 1990s, Grand left Cyberlife to form Cyberlife Research and focus on the production of new alife technologies, including work on a [[robotics|robotic]] life form he called Lucy as well as writing books about his research. The remainder of the company was renamed Creature Labs, and focused on [[video game development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=17_0_6_0_M8 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517100548/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=17_0_6_0_M8 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Creature Labs |publisher=Gamewaredevelopment.com |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref>
Sequels to ''Creatures'', including ''Creatures 2'', ''[[Creatures 3]]'' and the small-children's games ''Creatures Adventures'' and ''Creatures Playground'', were released by Creature Labs in subsequent years. ''Creatures Adventures'' won an EMMA Award in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010421032520/http://www.emma-foundation.org/prevWin.asp?section=2000 |archivedate=2001-04-21 |title=2000 Winners |publisher=The International EMMA Awards |date=2001-04-21 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> ''Creatures Playground'' was exhibited at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_playground.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20010417093344/http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_playground.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=17 April 2001 |title=Creatures Playground gets first outing at E3 in Los Angeles |publisher=Creature Labs |date=5 May 2000 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> and nominated for a [[BAFTA award]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/bafta/5_ie/5_NOMINATIONS_2000.htm |title=Interactive Entertainment Awards 2000 |publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts |accessdate=2012-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001214014300/http://www.bafta.org/bafta/5_ie/5_NOMINATIONS_2000.htm |archivedate=2000-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_BAFTA.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20010413232223/http://www.creaturelabs.com/creaturelabs/news/news_BAFTA.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 April 2001 |title=Creatures Playground nominated for BAFTA |publisher=Creature Labs |date=4 October 2000 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> The final major ''Creatures'' release, ''Docking Station'', was made available for download from the company's web site in 2001.<ref name="highlights">{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010522113910/http://www.creatures.co.uk/ |archivedate=2001-05-22 |title=Highlights |publisher=The Creatures Community |date=2001-05-22 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
Development was suspended on future ''Creatures'' games on March 20, 2003, when Creature Labs ceased operations, but development and trademark rights have since been purchased by Gameware Development, Ltd. Gameware has revived the Creatures Developer Network, the shop, the forums, the Docking Station server, and has released many before-purchasable tools and add-ons for free.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/diary.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517015602/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/diary.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Gameware Development |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref>
Gameware staff that previously worked on ''Creatures'' developed a convergent media game for the [[BBC]] called ''[[BAMZOOKi]]''.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/>
In 2004, the ''Creatures'' games have been re-released in combination packs under the names ''Creatures: The Albian Years'' (C1, C2), ''Creatures Exodus'' (C3, DS) and ''Creatures Village'' (CA, CP). The Albian Years, and Exodus include the separate games, whereas Village has merged Adventures and Playground into a single game.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/>
[[Kutoka Interactive]], a Canadian children's software company, has created releases of ''Creatures Exodus'' (Kutoka) and ''Creatures Village'' (Kutoka Kids) that are compatible with both Apple's [[Mac OS X]] and [[Windows XP]].<ref name="gamewaredevelopment1"/> They were released on 30 September 2005, and can be purchased either directly from Kutoka or from other online stores.
In November 2009, [[GOG.com]] announced that they were offering ''Creatures: The Albian Years'', ''Creatures Exodus'' and ''Creatures Village'' for sale on their site as digital downloads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gog.com/en/news/new_release_creatures/2009/11 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124125929/http://www.gog.com/en/news/new_release_creatures/2009/11 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-24 |title=News - New release: Creatures |publisher=GOG.com |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> In 2011, ''Creatures 3: Raised in Space'', a [[PlayStation One]] game, was re-released on the [[PlayStation Plus]] service.<ref name="EUapril11">{{cite web|url=http://blog.eu.playstation.com/2011/04/06/the-biggest-playstation-plus-month-yet/ |title=The Biggest PlayStation Plus Month Yet |publisher=[[PlayStation Blog]] |date=April 6, 2011 |accessdate=August 23, 2013}}</ref>
In 2011, [[Fishing Cactus]] announced they were developing Creatures 4, to be demonstrated at that year's [[gamescom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2011/08/11/creatures-4-1st-screenshot-creature-artwork/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » Creatures 4 1st screenshot & creature artwork |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2011-08-11 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> A second demonstration was exhibited at [[Gamescom#Gamescom 2012|gamescom 2012]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2012/08/22/creatures-4-at-the-gamescom-2012-in-koln/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » Creatures 4 at the gamescom 2012 in Köln! |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2012-08-22 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> ''Creatures 4'' is Fishing Cactus's most complex game to date.<ref name=LSDJV>{{cite AV media | people =Christophe Clementi (Interviewer) | year =2013|trans-title=Interview With Fishing Cactus on Creatures 4 for RTBF - The Week in Video Games|title=Interview Fishing Cactus Creatures 4 pour RTBF - LSDJV | language = French | url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41exEYDie54 | publisher = La Semaine Du Jeu Video ([[RTBF]]) | location = Belgium}}</ref> ''Creatures 4'' appeared at the 2012 [[Paris Games Week]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parisgamesweek.com/en/game/creatures-4 |title=Creatures 4 du Salon du jeu vidéo Paris Games Week |publisher=Parisgamesweek.com |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029085010/http://www.parisgamesweek.com/en/game/creatures-4 |archivedate=October 29, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures4-thegame.co.uk/news/paris-games-week-2012 |title=Paris Games Week 2012 | Creatures 4 Official Website |publisher=Creatures4-thegame.co.uk |date=2012-11-07 |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117034544/http://www.creatures4-thegame.co.uk/news/paris-games-week-2012 |archivedate=January 17, 2013 }}</ref> In May 2013, Fishing Cactus announced that they and BigBen were partnering with [[ProSiebenSat.1 Media|ProSiebenSat.1 Games]] as a distributor, and that the name of the game would be changed from ''Creatures 4'' to ''Creatures Online''.<ref name="CreaturesOnline">{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2013/05/28/c4-update-euro-distribution-of-creatures-online/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » C4 update: Euro distribution of Creatures Online |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2013-04-24 |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref> Another demo was shown at [[GamesCom 2013|gamescom 2013]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2013/08/23/creatures-online-news-from-gamescom-2013/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » Creatures Online: News from gamescom 2013 |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2013-08-23 |accessdate=2013-10-03}}</ref> Julien Hamaide, a developer of Creatures Online, presented about it at the Game/AI Conference 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gameaiconf.com/conference/program/ |title=Game/AI Conf. is evolving into nucl.ai |publisher=Gameaiconf.com |date=2015-07-22 |accessdate=2015-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gameaiconf.com/recording/2014-creatures/ |title=Creatures 3 Online | Game/AI Conference™ |publisher=Gameaiconf.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-12}}</ref> In September 2015, Fishing Cactus halted the development of Creatures Online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2016/01/21/creatures-status-fishing-cactus-official-statement/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » Creatures Status – Fishing Cactus Official Statement |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2016-01-21 |accessdate=2016-03-10}}</ref>
In 2016, [[Spil Games]] announced that they had bought the ''Creatures'' [[intellectual property]] from BigBen and were developing a free-to-play mobile game called ''Creatures Family'' to be released in 2017.<ref>{{cite press release|author=Scott Johnston |url=http://www.spilgames.com/press/creatures-reborn-mobile-age/ |title=Creatures reborn for the mobile age |publisher=Spil Games |date=2016-03-09 |accessdate=2016-03-10}}</ref>
==Gameplay== Basic gameplay consists of hatching some creatures, usually norns, and guiding them to reach maturity and to breed more creatures, with the goal of a more intelligent future population.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/2874/designers_notebook_more_sexes_.php |title=Features - Designer's Notebook: More Sex(es) in Computer Games |publisher=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> Words can be taught to creatures by a learning computer (for verbs) or by repeating the name of the object while the creature is looking at it. After a creature understands language, the player can instruct their creature by typing in instructions, which the creature may choose to obey.<ref name=CNETreview>{{cite web|url=http://reviews.cnet.com/pc-games/creatures-2-pc/4505-9696_7-30977365.html |title=Creatures 2 review (PC) |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=1998-11-13 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> The player cannot force creatures to do anything.<ref name="edge">{{cite journal|journal=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|date=July 1996|location=United Kingdom|pages=12–13|title=Artificial Intelligence enters next Millennium}}</ref> The player is represented by a disembodied hand in the world, and the hand can attempt to teach creatures by tickling them as a reward or punishing creatures by slapping them.<ref name=CNETreview/> (For ''Creatures Village'', aimed at very young players, tickling is done by a feather wand, and punishment is represented by a [[squirt bottle]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Albers|first=Marcus|title=Creatures: Village|url=http://www.insidemacgames.com/reviews/view.php?ID=665&Page=1|publisher=[[Inside Mac Games]] |date=13 March 2006 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/CVManual.pdf |title=Creatures Village Manual |format=PDF |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005005003/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/CVManual.pdf |archivedate=October 5, 2013 }}</ref>) Older norns can also teach concepts to younger norns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.electric-games.com/reviews/creatures.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050818202754/http://www.electric-games.com/reviews/creatures.html |title=Electric Games Review: Creatures by Cyberlife Technologies/Mindscape |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2005-08-18 |accessdate=2013-10-03 |archivedate=2005-08-18}}</ref> Norns may also express to the player how they are feeling. The language aspect was incorporated to promote a relationship between norns and players,<ref>{{cite book|last=Grand|first=Steve|title=Human cognition and social agent technology|year=2000|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9027251398|page=374|editor=Dautenhahn, Kerstin|chapter=The Emergence of Personality: How to Create Souls from Cells}}</ref> allowing players to [[anthropomorphise]] their creatures.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hansen|first=Suzy|title=The emotional machine|url=http://www.salon.com/2002/01/02/grand/|newspaper=[[Salon.com]] |date=3 January 2002 }}</ref> A complete life cycle is modelled for the creatures - childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and [[senescence]], each with their own particular needs.<ref name="aigamedev1">{{cite web|url=http://aigamedev.com/open/review/creatures-ai/ |author=Champandard, Alex J. |title=Evolving with Creatures’ AI: 15 Tricks to Mutate into Your Own Game |publisher=AiGameDev.com |date=2007-10-01 |accessdate=2013-03-01}}</ref> Breeding is depicted in the game as "a delicate affair", and is shown in the game by "a long kissing sound followed by a pop".<ref>{{cite book|last=Simpson|first=Toby|title=Creatures : official strategies & secrets|year=1997|publisher=Sybex|location=San Francisco|page=40|isbn=978-0782122022}}</ref> The gameplay is designed to foster an emotional bond between the player and their creatures. Death has real consequences - the individual norns do not return after they die.<ref name="aigamedev1"/> All creatures are [[bipedal]], but there are some variant appearances that are genetically-linked.<ref name=GrandCliffAAMAS>{{cite journal|last1=Grand|first1=Stephen|last2=Cliff|first2=Dave|author-link2=Dave Cliff (computer scientist)|title=Creatures: Entertainment Software Agents with Artificial Life|journal=[[Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems]]|date=1998|volume=1|issue=1|pages=39–57|doi=10.1023/A:1010042522104}}</ref> Some alternate play styles include "wolfling runs", where the player may not intervene in their creatures' lives,<ref name="gamewaredevelopment3">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=481_0_6_0_C |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517105227/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=481_0_6_0_C |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Creatures 3 Behaviour FAQs |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> or even norn torture.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/news/topstories/0,1287,13293,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011121150053/http://www.wired.com/news/topstories/0%2C1287%2C13293%2C00.html |archivedate=2001-11-21 |title=Virtual Sadism |publisher=Wired.com |date=2001-11-21 |accessdate=2012-12-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Trying to selectively breed or engineer certain traits into the population is also popular, for example, coloured creatures, norns with a better [[immune system]],<ref name=TCGDE/><ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|date=October 1997|title=Finding companionship in a digital age|pages=56–63}}</ref> or a less-aggressive grendel.
===Species=== ;Norns
A Norn is an AIL (Artificial intelligent life) species, the development and survival of which constitute the main thematic elements of the program.
Norns are playful, all-trusting, naive creatures that love to explore. This is often the reason for their downfall, suffering, and death. They are more susceptible to disease in comparison to Ettins and Grendels, and in old age they may fall prey to a wasting disease that prevents them from absorbing certain nutrients.
Grand wished Norns to be endearing and for players to keep them as pets - that they should be independent and stubborn, like toddlers, and that the design of the norn should be appealing to as many people as possible, and that the player should care about the norns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/Library/History/lib_history_norn.htm |title=The evolution of a species |publisher=Creatures.org.uk |date=March 1994 |accessdate=2012-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010212093320/http://www.creatures.co.uk/Library/History/lib_history_norn.htm |archivedate=2001-02-12}}</ref> Reviewers have compared the Norns' visual design to the Mogwai of the ''[[Gremlins]]'' film series.<ref name="Jepsen C2">{{cite journal|last=Jepsen|first=Dawn|title=They're Dead, Jim: Natural Selection Goes Awry in This Depressing Update|journal=[[Computer Gaming World]]|date=January 1999|issue=174|pages=364, 366}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unwinnable.com/2012/01/27/playing-god-on-death-motherhood-and-creatures/#more-26486 |title=Playing God: On Death, Motherhood and ‘Creatures’ |author=Frank, Jenn |publisher=Unwinnable |date=2012-01-27 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> The Shee originally created the Norns as a mixture of [[valet]] and pet. According to the Creatures Labs website, they spread across the galaxy through the Warp and evolved into various variations, including but not restricted to: Toxic Norn,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=503_0_6_0_M26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517015813/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=503_0_6_0_M26 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=The Toxic Norn Story |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> Treehugger Norn<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=504_0_6_0_M26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140205201459/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=504_0_6_0_M26 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-02-05 |title=The Treehugger Norn Story |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> and Magma Norns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=501_0_6_0_M26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517020401/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/creatures_more.php?id=501_0_6_0_M26 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=The Magma Norn Story |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> The spread of Norns throughout the galaxy is related to the mysterious disappearance of the Shee from Albia (from the point of view of the Norns). It may also be a sign of how the Shee fared in their attempt to find a habitable planet.
In the games, the Norns have their own simulated biochemistry, haploid genetics, and [[neural network]] to serve as a brain. From Creatures 2 onwards, Norns also possess organs determined by their genetics;<ref name="Gamasutra C2"/> mutation and injury can render these defunct, with typically fatal consequences. Each of these has grown somewhat over the course of the series, allowing the creatures to become more complex and intelligent. Norns are omnivores and eat a variety of foods, including carrots, lemons, seeds, insects, fish, honey, and other things. The Norns that the player starts with require some degree of training and discipline from the player in order to make good decisions to maintain their health; however, later on they can evolve to be more independent and hardy, with better-developed instincts and a more robust biochemistry. The player can take advantage of this to breed certain colours or traits through artificial selection, and through many generations the changes can become quite pronounced.
Norns are very social animals,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jepsen|first=Dawn|title=It's Alive: ''Creatures'' Is Bound To Tickle Your Fancy|journal=[[Computer Gaming World]]|date=November 1997|issue=160|pages=314–315}}</ref> sometimes to the extent that they will prefer to play with other norns than to eat.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971016000951/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_june2.htm |url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_june2.htm |title=Creatures Newsletter June p.2 |publisher=Cyberlife |archivedate=1997-10-16 |accessdate=2013-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312050032/http://worldvillage.com/wv/gamezone/html/reviews/creature.htm |url=http://worldvillage.com/wv/gamezone/html/reviews/creature.htm |title=Creatures |publisher=Gamer's Zone |author=Meinfelder, Edmond |archivedate=2009-03-12 |accessdate=2013-01-15}}</ref>
;Shee [[File:Shee statue.png|thumb|right|The statue of a Shee in ''[[Creatures 2]]''. This is one of very few official in-game appearances of the Shee. (There are more hidden deeper in.)]] The Shee are a race of absent-minded scientists. They are the original inhabitants of Albia, and the creators of the Norns, Ettins, and Grendels.
The Shee are all inventors, and make most of their inventions to save time on tasks that would have taken but a few minutes otherwise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/Library/History/lib_history_shee.htm |title=Shee Mystery Unfolds |publisher=creatures.org.uk |accessdate=2012-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001214182000/http://www.creatures.co.uk/Library/History/lib_history_shee.htm |archivedate=December 14, 2000 }}</ref>
Most of their discoveries are made by accident, and as such, they sequenced their own [[DNA]] and eliminated all genetic defects, before discovering the wheel.
Millennia ago, the Shee had left the disk-shaped world of Albia, as they desired to live on a "more spherical world". They created the Shee Ark, took along some Norns, Ettins, and various animals and plants, and set out for their new home. The Shee Ark, like all Shee spacecraft, was itself a living creature grown from scratch, and used "Bioenergy" (the energy of living things, used to balance the game) to perform its various functions.
Early concepts of the Shee had them as merely a more advanced life form than the Norns, not their creators.<ref name=definitivearticle>{{cite web|url=http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/definitivearticle.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927203105/http://fp.cyberlifersrch.plus.com/creaturesarchive/definitivearticle.htm |author=Grand, Steve |archivedate=2008-09-27 |title=Small Furry Creatures: The Definitive Article |publisher=Cyberlife Research |date=4 November 1994 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref>
;Ettins <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Ettin.jpg|thumb|left|123px|An Ettin from [[Creatures|Creatures 3]].]] -->Ettins are a species in ''[[Creatures 2]]'' and ''[[Creatures 3]]''.
Ettins were created by the Shee to help them on their experiments, especially when using machinery. They made them like machines so much, they tend to steal bits for themselves, often taking them to wherever they consider their home.
''C2'' Ettins behave rather differently; they tend to lead a sad and lonely life underground with no one but Pitz and the occasional Grendel for company. The backstory in the guides and manual, as well as the opening sequence, reveals that they once lived in the desert at the top of Albia and, true to their nature, built the pyramid that sits there. The actual use (if any) of the pyramid is unknown.
Ettins were introduced into the ''Creatures'' series in ''C2'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creatures.co.uk/creatures2_news1.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19981206040212/http://www.creatures.co.uk/creatures2_news1.htm |archivedate=1998-12-06 |title=Creatures 2 Newsletter 1. |publisher=creatures.org.uk |date=1998-12-06 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> having been revealed to the world after the volcanic eruption.
An early concept of the Ettins described them as insignificant "small, lizard-like creatures", who were often kept as pets by Norns.<ref name=mythography/>
The Ettins in ''Creatures 2'' were infertile; however, in ''Creatures 3'', there were two Ettins aboard the Shee Ark at most times (both female), and it was possible to get them to breed if two of them were placed in the Gene Splicer machine to create a male Ettin.
An in-depth exploration of the genetics and neurology of the Ettins in ''Creatures 2'' revealed that they were constantly in pain, apparently by design. This discovery was met by fan uproar.
;Grendels <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:C2 Grendelimage.jpg|right|thumb|A [[Creatures 2]] Grendel]] --> Grendels are the green-skinned, red-eyed antagonists of the Norns, over which the player has little control, stealing food and injuring individual Norns. They also carry diseases harmful to Norns.<ref name=TCGDE/> The early concepts of their appearance described them as "resembling a huge, titanium spider".<ref name=mythography/>
In the unmodified ''Creatures 1'' and ''2'', Grendels do not reproduce, being born infertile. Generally, only one Grendel is alive in the world of Albia at a time. In ''Creatures 3'', two Grendels were alive aboard the Shee Ark at most times (both male), but it was possible to get them to breed and have offspring if both were placed in the Gene Splicer machine and used to create a female Grendel.
In all three games, Grendels are automatically produced by a "Mother" machine; in ''Creatures 3'', however, it is possible to ensure that there are no Grendels in the game by killing any existing grendels (e.g. in the [[airlock]]) and then waiting by the mother, then placing any eggs into water (the [[piranha]] pool) so that they cannot hatch.
The Grendels were another genetically engineered creation of the Shee, albeit an accidental one. They were certainly not what the Shee were trying to get as a result from their experiments, and were considered to be harmful, useless monsters. However, some of the evil Shee (known as the Banshee) believed the Grendels were genetically superior to the Norns, and kept some for improvement.
It is possible to cross a Norn with a Grendel, creating a 'Grenorn'.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/news/topstories/0,1287,5037,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011129065439/http://www.wired.com/news/topstories/0%2C1287%2C5037%2C00.html |archivedate=2001-11-29 |title=Digital DNA Swap Meet |publisher=Wired.com |date=2001-11-29 |accessdate=2012-12-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971015235359/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july.htm |url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_newsletter_july.htm |title=Creatures July Newsletter Page 1 |publisher=Cyberlife |archivedate=1997-10-15 |accessdate=2012-12-12}}</ref>
The Creatures community has appeared to adopt the Grendel as an underdog figure, creating a "Grendel Liberation Front" - despite being intended to add stress to Norns' lives, players began to tame their Grendels.<ref name=TCGDE/>
===User Interface=== {{expand section|date=November 2012}} In each of the games, players interact with the world through the use of a graphical hand as the player's mouse in the main visual area of the game. In ''Creatures'' and ''Creatures 2'', players can use applets in a toolbar, often called Kits, along the top of the game window, to access many functions, such as getting their first norn eggs, naming and photographing their norns, monitoring the health and general biochemistry of the norns and administering medicines, monitoring pregnancies, injecting objects into the world, and recording deceased norns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_toolbar.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971016002046/http://www.cyberlife.co.uk/creatures_toolbar.htm |archivedate=1997-10-16 |title=THE CREATURES TOOLBAR. |publisher=Cyberlife |date=1997-10-16 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/C1Manual.pdf |title=Creatures Deluxe Breeder's Manual |format=PDF |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004224453/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/C1Manual.pdf |archivedate=October 4, 2013 }}</ref> ''Creatures 2'' introduced an Ecology Kit and Neuroscience Kit.<ref name=C2manual>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/C2Manual.pdf |title=Creatures 2 Manual |format=PDF |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004232906/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/C2Manual.pdf |archivedate=October 4, 2013 }}</ref>
In Creature 3 and Docking Station, players still use a hand as their mouse to interact with creatures and the world, but the main game area does not have toolbars like in Creatures and Creatures 2, but instead has areas along the sides of the screens with buttons that the user can press to move to different locations, view the current creatures in the world, manage an inventory of items, and change game settings.
Charlie Brooker regarded the level of detail shown in the monitoring kits as "terrifying",<ref name="Brooker">{{cite web|last=Brooker|first=Charlie|title=Creatures|url=http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2854/creatures|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130120064244/http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2854/creatures|dead-url=yes|archive-date=20 January 2013|publisher=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|accessdate=9 December 2012|date=12 Aug 2001}}</ref> and it has been argued that the detailed monitoring kits highlight the artificiality of the norns.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Meer|first1=Alec|title=Have You Played… Creatures?|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/12/20/have-you-played-creatures/|accessdate=16 January 2018|work=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|date=20 December 2016}}</ref> Peter Smith disliked the limitation of C1 that the player is "limited to seeing areas that you've tagged as favorite places or that are currently inhabited by Norns," and found it difficult to correctly reward and punish the creatures.<ref name="cdmag2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdmag.com/articles/010/013/creatures_review.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031027104034/http://www.cdmag.com/articles/010/013/creatures_review.html|archivedate=2003-10-27 |title=Creatures Review |author=Smith, Peter |publisher=[[Computer Games Strategy Plus]] |date=1998-01-31 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> Creatures 2 introduced an angel and devil glyph which appears next to the hand to show you whether you are about to reward or punish your creature.<ref name="C2manual" /> Jim Brumbaugh, in reviewing ''Creatures'', disliked the amount of typing that was needed to communicate with the creatures, but found the menu system "highly user friendly." He noted also that there was only one way that the player could save, when the player exited the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avault.com/reviews/print_review.asp?game=creatur |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060303193810/http://www.avault.com/reviews/print_review.asp?game=creatur |title=Creatures |publisher=Adrenaline Vault |date=July 16, 1997 |archivedate=2006-03-03 |accessdate=2012-12-08 |author=Brumbaugh, Jim}}</ref> Eddie Walou praised the simplified user interface of ''Creatures 4'', saying that earlier games felt like you had to have your [[Bachelor's degree|BAC]] to understand.<ref name="Walou" /> Kahn Lusth, writing for [[Canard PC]], enjoyed the new interface of ''Creatures Online'' for communicating with creatures, where with a click of the mouse the player can choose suggestions to guide their creatures, describing it as more convenient than typing keywords.<ref name="CanardPC" /> To improve the ergonomics on the [[iOS]] system, a 'rubber-band' system has been created for ''Creatures Online'', where the player draws a line between the norn and an object. When the finger is lifted, the available instructions appear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creatures-online.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&p=6046#p6046 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103223513/http://creatures-online.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&p=6046 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-11-03 |title=Forum • View topic - Weekly update #8 - 23 September - 02 October 2013 |last=Schiaratura |first=Sophie |publisher=Creatures Online Official Site |accessdate=2013-11-03}}</ref>
===Environment=== {{expand section|date=December 2012}} While the initial pitch was for a desktop pet that could interact with other Windows programs, for example, [[Windows Media Player]],<ref name=initialpitch/> as the game developed, the need for a self-contained world became more apparent. The world was named "Albia", after [[Albion]], and one of the goals of gameplay became to explore Albia.<ref name=rationale/><ref name=definitivearticle/> Grand thought that having the creatures inhabit a rich, "messy", world, and to be able to interact with it in many ways would help creatures' personalities to emerge.<ref name="grand352"/> The backdrop for ''Creatures'' was created by taking photographs of a physical model of the world,<ref name=mainhistory/> part of which is now housed at [[The Centre for Computing History]].<ref>[http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/det/42694/Creatures-Model/ Creatures Model - Computing History<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The world is rendered in [[2.5D]], and the world can smoothly scroll to follow a creature. The world contains many different items, which creatures can interact with in a variety of ways. Objects are written using an [[object-oriented programming]] technique - each item has their own scripts which determine how they interact with creatures and with other objects. Objects are detected by a creature by being in its line of sight, which excites a neuron dedicated to that class of objects.<ref name="autogenerated1996">{{cite web|url=http://mrl.snu.ac.kr/courses/CourseSyntheticCharacter/grand96creatures.pdf |title=Creatures: Artificial Life Autonomous Software Agents for Home Entertainment |author1=Grand, Steve |author2=Cliff, Dave |author3=Mahotra, Anil. |year=1996 |publisher=Millennium Technical Report 9601; University of Sussex Technical Report CSRP434 |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> The object-oriented approach means that the games are highly [[Mod (video gaming)|modifiable]].<ref name="edge"/> Some of the items in the world are dangerous to norns.<ref>{{cite web|last=James|first=Bonnie|title=Creatures|url=http://www.elecplay.com/pc/creatures.html|publisher=[[The Electronic Playground]]|accessdate=9 December 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970801040044/http://www.elecplay.com/pc/creatures.html|archivedate=1 August 1997|date=June 11, 1997}}</ref>
In ''Creatures 2'', the environment became more complex, with a "Complete working eco-system, including weather, seasons and a functioning food-chain. The plants seed and spread around the environment if conditions allow. The result of this is a very "real" feeling world that adapts around the player."<ref name="Gamasutra C2"/>
In ''Creatures 3'' and ''Docking Station'', the game was set on a spaceship. The environment became more segmented into areas called "metarooms", small biomes, each with their own ecosystem. Players could download and add new metarooms to their games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/C3manual.pdf |title=Creatures 3 Manual |format=PDF |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12}}{{Dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref><ref name="gamewaredevelopment4">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads/DSManual.pdf |title=Creatures Docking Station Manual |format=PDF |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2012-11-12}}{{Dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref>
==Games in the series== <!-- going to mix this section so it flows better (and find the missing dates), and have an overview of each of the three parts. feel free to jump in and help. -->
There were six major ''Creatures'' releases from Creature Labs. In addition to the three principal games, the ''Docking Station'' add-on (generally referenced as a separate game) and two children's games were released.
===''On Albia'' (later re-released as ''Creatures: The Albian Years'')===
====''Creatures''==== The original ''Creatures'' game, released in the United Kingdom and Australia in November 1996 and in North America in July 1997, took place on the fictional disc-shaped world Albia. While the "faces" of the disc were uninhabitable, the "rim" of Albia was home to a complicated [[natural environment|environment]] much like Earth's. Here lay an abandoned system of [[laboratory|laboratories]] left over by the Shee, an advanced race that had suddenly left the planet many years earlier in order to find a more stable world. In these laboratories and environments, the player was able to hatch new Norns from leftover [[egg (biology)|eggs]] and re-inhabit the world of Albia. According to Millenium, every copy of ''Creatures'' contains a unique starting set of eggs, whose genomes are not replicated on any other copy of the game.<ref name="NGen23"/> An expansion pack, called "Life Kit #1" was released for purchase later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdmag.com/articles/010/034/lifekit_review.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030705043628/http://www.cdmag.com/articles/010/034/lifekit_review.html |archivedate=2003-07-05 |title=Creatures Life Kit #1 Review |author=Smith, Peter |publisher=[[Computer Games Strategy Plus]] |date=1998-01-31 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref>
''Creatures'' sold 100,000 copies by November 1997. At the time, John Moore of Mindscape explained that the company "expect[s] to sell more than 200,000 ''Creatures'' by the end of the year."<ref name=sales1>{{cite web | author=Anderson, Jill | title=Mindscape Sells 100,000 ''Creatures'' | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000520041544/http://headline.gamespot.com/news/97_11/03_creature/index.html | url=http://headline.gamespot.com:80/news/97_11/03_creature/index.html | archivedate=May 20, 2000 | work=[[GameSpot]] | date=November 3, 1997 | deadurl=yes | access-date=August 3, 2018 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====''Creatures 2''====
[[File:Creatures 2 game new Norn.PNG|right|thumb|Creatures 2 added 16-bit graphics and a larger world]]
''[[Creatures 2]]'', released on September 30, 1998, took place many years after the first game, after a devastating [[natural disaster]] (or, as explained in later games, a devastating Shee disaster) had changed the [[landscape]] of Albia dramatically and opened up new areas of the world. New [[technology]] and [[species]] were made available to the [[Player (game)|player]], and the creatures themselves had been provided with "considerably more sensory input, more actions they can take, and improved brain dynamics".<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|date=July 1998|title=Creatures 2|page=23}}</ref> Despite the great change in environment, including a "complete working eco-system",<ref name="Gamasutra C2">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/3271/from_creatures_to_androids.php |title=Features - From Creatures to Androids |publisher=Gamasutra |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref> the focus of the game remained the same. Creatures 2 Deluxe (with Life Kit) soon followed. 200,000 copies of ''Creatures 2'' were immediately shipped upon its release.<ref name=TCGDE>{{cite journal|last=Cliff|first=Dave|author2=Grand, Stephen|title=The Creatures Global Digital Ecosystem|journal=Artificial Life|year=1999|volume=5|issue=1|pages=77–93|doi=10.1162/106454699568683|pmid=10421678}}</ref> Two expansion packs, Life Kit 1 and Life Kit 2, were released for C2.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads_more.php?id=447_0_8_0_M15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517102057/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads_more.php?id=447_0_8_0_M15 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Creatures 2 Life Kit 1 |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2013-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads_more.php?id=34_0_8_0_M15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517102035/http://www.gamewaredevelopment.com/downloads_more.php?id=34_0_8_0_M15 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-05-17 |title=Creatures 2 Life Kit 2 |publisher=Gameware Development |accessdate=2013-01-15}}</ref> ''Creatures 2'' was considered "much more difficult" than ''C1'',<ref>{{cite journal|last=Clarkson|first=Mark|title=Creatures 2: Power-ups and Help on How to Keep Your Norns Alive|journal=[[Computer Gaming World]]|date=February 1999|issue=175|page=258}}</ref> and the new, more challenging environment and norn biology was described as frustrating, but that after installing a new genome and going through successive generations, the Norns seemed smarter.<ref name="Jepsen C2"/> Nick Walkland described the gameplay as a "labour of love", noting that the challenge was to sustain your Norns' lives.<ref>{{cite web|last=Walkland|first=Nick|title=Creatures 2|url=http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2856/creatures-2|publisher=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]]|accessdate=9 December 2012|date=12 Aug 2001|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130119175808/http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2856/creatures-2|archivedate=19 January 2013|df=}}</ref> Sid Fisk of Gamezilla criticized the audio for Creatures 2 for not alerting him when his creature was near-death, but playing a "funeral dirge" as the body left the screen.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fisk|first1=Sid|title=Creatures 2 by Mindscape & Cyberlife Technology Ltd.|url=http://www.gamezilla.com/reviews/c/creatures2.asp|website=Gamezilla|accessdate=10 September 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010622224025/http://www.gamezilla.com/reviews/c/creatures2.asp|archivedate=22 June 2001|date=24 November 1998}}</ref>
===''After Leaving Albia'' (later re-released as ''Creatures Exodus'')===
====''Creatures 3''==== ''[[Creatures 3]]'', released on November 4, 1999, took a detour from the first two games. It took place on the [[starship|spaceship]] that the Shee had used to flee Albia. The ship was divided into many carefully controlled [[natural environment|environment]]s (Norn Terrarium, Jungle Terrarium, Desert Terrarium, Marine Terrarium). ''Creatures 3'' was much more technologically focused, including many agents which could be connected in various ways to perform tasks.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000821070502/http://www.gamecenter.com/Reviews/Item/Cont/0%2C7%2C0-3763_2%2C00.html |url=http://www.gamecenter.com/Reviews/Item/Cont/0,7,0-3763_2,00.html |title=Creatures 3 |publisher=Game Center.com |archivedate=2000-08-21 |accessdate=2012-12-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Still, the goal was to [[experiment]] with the three principal species and create a living world out of an empty ship. ''Creatures 3'' included a "new social element",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2857/creatures-3 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121042538/http://m.computerandvideogames.com/2857/creatures-3 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-21 |title=Creatures 3 | ComputerAndVideoGames.com |publisher=[[ComputerAndVideoGames.com]] |date=2001-08-12 |accessdate=2012-12-08}}</ref> by which norns could remember relationships they've formed with other creatures better.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment3"/>
====''Docking Station''==== The final major ''Creatures'' release was ''Docking Station'', an [[Internet]]-based add-on to ''Creatures 3'', released free of charge on the ''Creatures'' web site on March 27, 2001.<ref name="highlights"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ign.com/articles/2001/03/27/creatures-gets-new-creatures |title=Creatures Gets New Creatures |publisher=IGN |accessdate=2012-11-12}}</ref> It was intended as a way to sell ''Creatures 3'' (you could dock the worlds of the two games together, hence the name ''"Docking" Station'') and extra packs of Norn breeds. ''Docking Station'' has an intermittent reminder screen that encourages users to buy ''Creatures 3''.
''Docking Station'' added the possibility of interaction between individual player worlds; Norns could 'travel' to other online worlds via a central server, players could [[online chat|chat]] to other online players, and it was possible to track Norns (and their offspring) that had been present in their worlds via the ''Docking Station'' website.<ref name="gamewaredevelopment4"/> While ''Docking Station'' was released late in the series' run, it changed gameplay (and the potential of the series) dramatically. One reviewer stated that it opened up a whole new world for her online.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010607075048/http://gamezone.com/gzreviews/r18445.htm |url=http://gamezone.com/gzreviews/r18445.htm |title=Creatures Docking Station |publisher=GameZone |archivedate=2001-06-07 |accessdate=2012-12-12}}</ref> Another reviewer criticised the online portion of the game, as it requires the player to find online buddies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cadotte|first=Joseph|title=Creatures: Exodus|url=http://www.insidemacgames.com/reviews/view.php?ID=664 |publisher=[[Inside Mac Games]] |date=15 September 2006 }}</ref> Docking Station also expanded considerably on the game mythos, including the introduction of an 'anti-Shee', the Banshee (a Grendel/Shee hybrid).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creaturelabs.com/creatures/expansion/banshee.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20021208182711/http://www.creaturelabs.com/creatures/expansion/banshee.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2002-12-08 |title=The Banshee Grendels |publisher=Creature Labs |accessdate=2013-03-01}}</ref>
===''Creatures Online''=== ''Creatures Online'' was a planned sequel to the game, which was being developed by Fishing Cactus. The game was announced as ''Creatures 4'' in Fishing Cactus's blog in May 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.fishingcactus.com/index.php/2011/05/18/announcing-creatures-4-on-ios-mac-and-pc/ |title=Fishing Cactus development blog » Blog Archive » Announcing Creatures 4 on iOS, Mac and PC |publisher=Blog.fishingcactus.com |date=2011-05-18 |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Creatures Online was to have 5 worlds, was to be completely in 3D graphics instead of [[2.5D]]<ref name="autogenerated1996"/> pre-rendered graphics, and in-game currency was planned to buy Norns toys, food, etc. Creatures Online was designed to be a [[free-to-play]] game.
